post_content:
Welcome to Egypt Hidden Gems' Ultimate Guide, your treasure map during Egypt excavations. This guide was planned, created, and drafted by specialized native consultants for foreigners, travelers, bold explorers, and those who can’t get enough by just exploring the surface in a fixed, pre-planned program. “You are going to Taste what Egyptians enjoy every day, celebrate their own drinks, dance all night long, or even join morning activities and water sports by the Nile River.” This is your ultimate guide to live like an Egyptian for one day or more.

Egyptian Food Experience

  Well, Egyptian cuisine is one of the wealthiest cuisines you might encounter. That you would empty my stomach days before heading to Egypt just to get the chance to taste every single plate that came across your eyes in these places. We can categorize Egyptian “commercial” food into three main categories: Authentic Egyptian food, Oriental and Eastern food, and Bedouin food. Let's have a quick and yummy look at what you are going to taste:  

Authentic Egyptian food:

Foul and Falafel: We can safely say that Egyptians are vegetarian people by nature, and there is no wonder As the Egyptians are considered one of the earliest people who discovered agriculture, You can start your breakfast with the famous and legendary Foul and Falafel Breakfast. We recommend some famous brands that have branches across any search on the map:
  1. Gad جاد  
  2. Bashandy بشندي
  3. Felfla فلفلة
  4. El Shabrawy  الشبراوي
  5. Arabiata   ارابياتا
  Masmat: For those who don’t know, a masmat is a place that serves kersha (Tripe), kaware3 (Hock), lesan (Tongue) or even animal private parts (Halali), and basically, any other animal body part most would think were inedible. But for many others, it is an extraordinary experience that might want to talk about later with colleagues and family back home. Here is one of Egyptian famous Masmats:
  1. Beggah بجة, عابدين
  2. Bahha بحه الناصريه
  3. Habayb Elsayeda. حبايب السيده
Luckily, these three veteran restaurants and many more Masmats are Adjacent to the ancient area of Abdeen Koshary: Let us return to the Egyptian natural planet-based diet and Mo Salah's Favorite plate ever, as per him. Just don’t worry. The world's most typical and commercial Oriental food is coming right after this light dish of Koshary that consists of Rice, Lentils, Macaroni, Vermicelli, Tomato sauce, Vegetable oil, Onions, Cumin, Coriander, Chickpeas all in just one cheap vegetarian salty cocktail, you can have it in restaurant, takeaway, or delivery and here are the most reliable brands that can afford you Koshary:
  1. Koshary El Tahrir.
  2. Sayed Hanafy.
  3. Abo Tarek.
  4. Tom and Basal.
  5. Koshary Hend.
 

Oriental and Eastern Cuisines 

You don’t have to visit Syria, Yemen, Turkey, or Palestine because all these cuisines are invading Egypt to compete with other international brand marks along with the Egyptian cuisine in the 110 million population republic of Egypt. Here are the best of the best out of every neighboring country to judge its cuisine properly:
  1. Shawarma El Reem شاورما الريم (Syrian).
  2. Hadramout حضرموت (Yemeni).
  3. Sultan Ayub السلطان أيوب (Turkish).
  4. Sobhy Kaber صبحي كابر (Egyptian).
  5. El Prince البرنس (Egyptian).
And after giving Egyptian food the golden medal, of course, you can check a specialized variety of Egyptian cuisine restaurants:
  1. Kasr Elkababgi قصر الكبابجي
  2. Studio Misr ستوديو مصر
  3. El Dahan - الدهان الأصل بتاع زمان 19554
  4. Asmak Resaurant Wadi Al Nile أسماك وادي النيل
  5. Ibn Hamido Seafood أسماك إبن حميدو
  Bedouin Cuisine: The most healthy and notorious food that might come across your nose, however, it is protein based cuisine, but the manner they treaded meat and chicken is so healthy yet so delicious, here are  more than must-visit Bedouin restaurants and villages while you are in Egypt:  
  1. Ghazal El Reem Bedouin Village  قرية غزال الريم للمأكولات البدوية التجمع الثالث
  2. Hany Village قرية هاني للمأكولات البدوية | فرع القاهرة
  3. Wahet Khattab واحة خطاب
  4. Wahet Saieed  واحة سعيد للاكلات البدوية والمشويات والمندي
  5. Legleisah Bedouin Cuisine لجليسة للمأكولات البدوية

Egypt Activities and NightLife

  Now it's time to burn some calories. After a new food experience, it's the Adrenaline time. We can categorize Egypt's activities between morning bird activities and Night owl activities; however, many of the morning activities are still available late-day, but it is us who want to keep your night available for one of the wealthiest nightlife countries around the world.

Morning Activities: 

  • Kayak, Rowing, Water Sports:

    Imagine yourself in a warm and calm river stream wearing your lifejacket and holding a paddle, doing this away from your home country; actually, no picture can describe the smell and breeze. We are recommending Nile Kayak Club for its variety of branches. You can go kayaking way south in Aswan, or Cairo, or even on the Mediterranean Sea in Alexandria.
Nile Kayak Club: https://www.nilekayakclub.org/blog-1 Greek Rowing Club: Greek Rowing Club  

  • Skiing and Snowboarding:

In case you’ve never seen snowy weather or missed your hometown's gloomy and cold weather, Cairo is here to make any of your dreams come true in the middle of the desserts where ski Egypt lying in Giza nearby the Pyramids, At Africa’s first indoor Ski resort and Snow Park, you can enjoy the spectacular 7,000 tons of real snow at below zero degrees. Get an unforgettable experience for everyone, with a range of unmatchable activities; enjoy Snow Park with all its different rides, learn to Ski or Snowboard on our Slope, and meet Snow Penguins through a unique encounter or the Penguins March. Ski Egypt: https://www.skiegy.com/en/  

  • Sky Diving:

    Have you ever dreamed of flying like a superhero? Now you can! From children to seniors, everybody can fly in a Wind Tunnel. Make your first flight and try this incredible new experience, or discover body flight as an exciting new sport.
Aerodium Egypt: https://www.indoorskydiving.world/tunnels/aerodium-egypt/  

  • Racing Karts:

Experience the thrill of speed at our premier kart racing location! Feel the adrenaline rush as you navigate through challenging tracks. Perfect for thrill-seekers and families. Safety is our priority, with top-notch equipment and trained staff. Race to the finish line and create lasting memories! GoKart Egypt: https://www.gokart-eg.com/  

  • Paintball at Adrenaline Park:

Paintball is one of the top adventurous and safe sports where players compete using air-pressured guns, which fire gelatin-colored bullets. It simulates the battlefield energetically. The main equipment of the game is Markers (Guns), Paintballs (Bullets), Masks, Overalls, Protection suits, and Gloves.  Adrenalin is the # 1 Paintball field in the Middle East and one of the top 100 worldwide in terms of player numbers, Court sizes, and quality.   Adrenaline Park: https://www.adrenalinegypt.com/ And here is a quick mention of the other Activities that you can enjoy while you are in Egypt: 
  • Rock Climbing and Bouldering: Mario high ropes
  • Escape Rooms and Mazes: Nightmare Escape Sherlocked Egypt Placebo - Role Playing Escape Rooms
  • Trampoline-Based games: Gravity Code Jumpedia Sky Zone Egypt
 

Nightlife Activities:

1) Cairo Jazz Club is the one place where you can enjoy live performances, drink and dance all together in one unforgettable night,  Here you can find the Event Calendar to carefully choose the performer you want to dance with their music all night long: https://cairojazzclub.com/events/ And here is the two locations in the two sides of Cairo: Cairo Jazz Club Cairo Jazz Club 610   2) El Sawy Culturewheel is a full-scale cultural center and the home for various activities and cultural events. Hundreds of concerts and musical events are on the daily basis calendar, including those for Oud, Jazz, and Musical Theatre for several Egyptian and Arab bands, singers, and entertainers. Event Calendar: https://www.culturewheel.com/en/events   3) Zawya Cinema: is a Cairo-based independent cinema platform with a mission to showcase and circulate quality films, don't worry, all the movies here are subtitled into English. Movies Calendar: http://zawyacinema.com/calendar   4) Cairo Opera House:  the leading performing arts venue in the Egyptian capital, but their website performs a lovely filtered calendar in which you can choose the theatre locations, the date, and the art type whether you want to watch Pallet, Music, Orchestras, or dance performance. Opera House Calendar: https://www.cairoopera.org/en/calendar/   5) Bibliotheca Alexandrina aims to revive the role of the Ancient Library of Alexandria in encouraging dialogue among scientists, philosophers, and artists alike. The BA Arts Center provides a forum dedicated to various expressions of all forms of art, and it seeks to realize the goals of the BA in being Egypt’s window on the world and the world’s window on Egypt in the artistic field. BA Calendar: https://www.bibalex.org/en/events/showevents   And here is a quick mention of Cairo and Alexandria Pubs and Bars that you can enjoy all night long while you are in Egypt:  Downtown Cairo: Pub 28, Undergroud Disco, Rooftop zamalek, Lotus Bar Maadi Cairo: Zulu, Tree Lounge Maadi Branch, Me Bar Zayed Cairo: The Tap West, Gigi, LA TABERNA New Cairo: The Tap East, Kazoku, SHINKŌ Cairo Alexandria: Calithea, Skyroof - Windsor Palace Hotel, NEO Lounge Alexandria Luxor: Royal Bar, Nile Bar & Lounge, Sundowner (Merrcure Luxor Karnak) Aswan: The Lounge Bar, Emy Bar Hurghada: Retro Pub HRG, Caribbean Bar, Hangover Bar & Grill Sharm Elshiekh: Buddha-Bar Sharm El-Sheikh, kash5a club

Are you searching for luxury hotels in Egypt and Cairo’s most beautiful luxury accommodations for an impeccable vacation? Look no further, for you have arrived at the perfect destination with Sun Pyramids! Drawing from our extensive background in orchestrating group excursions across Egypt, we present to you a glimpse into the sumptuous luxury and some Luxury Hotels Facts that await your arrival.

What are the Best Luxury Hotels in Cairo?

Le Meridien Cairo Airport

  It is directly linked to Terminal 3 by a convenient pedestrian bridge. This premier hotel stands as a beacon of lavish comfort in Cairo, with a unique fusion of accessibility and luxury. A brief tour of the hotel places you in the heart of Cairo’s dynamic rhythm. The Cairo Festival City Mall, just 3 km away, tempts you with its rich selection of retail and leisure options, while the Sun City Mall, a mere 2 km from your doorstep, enhances your urban adventure. Le Meridien Cairo Airport masterfully combines fancy with convenience, ensuring every aspect of your visit is catered to, including the benefit of on-site private parking.  
  • Location: Le Meridien Cairo Airport
  • Amenities: Dual swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport transfer service, On-site private parking. 
  • Food Information: Four on-site restaurants. 
Accommodations Available: Presidential Suite, Panoramic Suite, Studio Suite, Le Meridien Club Twin Room, Le Meridien Club King Room.

The Kempinski Nile Hotel

  Nestled in the Nile Corniche, the Kempinski Nile Hotel emerges as an ideal luxury accommodation in Cairo. More than just a place to stay, it offers a lavish retreat where elegance and ease combine. Kempinski prides itself on its luxurious chambers that radiate elegance. And the crowning jewel – a rooftop pool offering a wide view of the urban landscape and the noble Nile. Kempinski considered one of the 5-star hotels in Cairo, Egypt, near pyramids, just with a brief walk of 5 minutes brings you to the Egyptian Museum and the bustling heart of Cairo. A short drive of 20 minutes leads you to the inspiring Pyramids of Giza and the storied Cairo Citadel.  
  • Location: Nile Corniche, 12 Ahmed Ragheb Street, Garden City, Cairo
  • Amenities: Outdoor swimming pool, Free WiFi, Family rooms, Spa and wellness center
  • Food Information: 2 restaurants on site, Cuisine: Italian, International
Accommodations Available: Nile Deluxe Room Queen Bed, Superior Twin Room with City View, Nile Deluxe Suite, Madina Deluxe Suite, Presidential Suite.

The St. Regis Almasa Hotel

  Located in the New Administrative Capital and a mere 59 kilometers from the vibrant heart of Cairo, The St. Regis Almasa Hotel stands out as a crown jewel among the finest luxury hotels in Egypt This 5-star sanctuary offers free WiFi, allowing for seamless sharing of your unforgettable experiences. It's a stone’s throw away at just 66 kilometers. The Cairo Intl Conference Center infuses your visit with a blend of commerce and culture. And there’s no need to worry about the journey – Cairo International Airport is conveniently located only 50 kilometers from this wealthy retreat.    
  • Location: New Administrative Capital, Cairo
  • Amenities: 4 swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle, Family rooms
  • Food Information: 3 restaurants on site
Accommodations Available: Stand Alone Villa, Two-Bedroom Apartment, One `Bedroom Apartment, St.Regis Suite.

The Nile Ritz Carlton

  This hotel provides unparalleled amenities, a captivating vista, opulent decor, and a prime location, enabling visitors to explore numerous attractions in Cairo. A brief journey from this hotel leads you to El-Tahrir Square in the heart of Cairo, where the magnificent Egyptian Museum awaits. Indulge in an exquisite spa experience, fine dining, impeccable service, and plush lodging. The hotel houses an inviting fitness center, aiding guests in maintaining their workout routine. The hotel is also considered one of the 5-star hotels in Cairo, Egypt, near pyramids.
  • Location: 1113 Corniche El Nil, Cairo
  • Amenities: Outdoor swimming pool, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle, Family rooms
  • Food Information: 9 restaurants on site
Accommodations Available: Deluxe Guest room, 2 Doubles, Nile View, Terrace, Club Guest room, 2 Doubles, Museum view, City View, Ritz-Carlton Suite, 1 King, Nile view.

Dusit Thani Lakeview Cairo

  Situated on El Tesseen Street, the Dusit Thani Lakeview Cairo is a symbol of luxury living. This 5-star gem offers a range of exceptional facilities that epitomize the finest luxury hotels in Cairo. Moreover, Dusit Thani excels in the craft of indulgence. They effortlessly provide free airport transfers, ensuring your travel to and from this sanctuary is as seamless as possible. Here’s the highlight: as you revel in luxury, the hotel’s prime location situates you merely a short distance from Cairo International Airport. Additionally, the city’s renowned attractions are within reach, easily accessible via the extensive highways that surround this grand retreat.
  • Location: El Tesseen Street, Fifth Settlement, New Cairo City, Cairo
  • Amenities: 2 swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle (free), and Family rooms.
  • Food Information: 4 restaurants on site. Cuisine: Chinese, Indian, Japanese, Thai, Asian.
  • Accommodations Available: Deluxe Double Room, Honeymoon Package (1 Night), Special Offer – Deluxe Patio Room – Egyptian and Residents, Executive Suite, Dusit Suite, Deluxe Patio R

    Intercontinental Cairo Citystars

  Nestled adjacent to Omar Ibn El Khattab, the Intercontinental Cairo Citystars proudly ranks among Cairo’s finest luxury hotels. The allure of Intercontinental Cairo Citystars is not only its optimal location but also its accommodations that epitomize opulence. Adding to its sumptuous lodgings is the advantage of modern conveniences. Free WiFi ensures you stay connected, while 23 cutting-edge meeting rooms are prepared to facilitate your professional engagements. For frequent travelers, the cherry on top is the hotel’s strategic location – just a quick 10-minute drive from the vibrant Cairo International Airport. Intercontinental Cairo Citystars is not merely a hotel; it’s a sanctuary of elegance and comfort that rightfully claims its spot among Luxury Hotels in Egypt.
  • Location: Omar Ibn El Khattab, Heliopolis, Nasr City, Cairo
  • Amenities: Family rooms, Private parking, Spa and wellness center, Fitness center
Accommodations Available: One-bedroom suite with Ergonomic Flex Space, Premium Twin Room with Ergonomic Flex Space, Premium King Room, Diplomatic Suite – Smoking.

Royal Maxim Palace Kempinski Cairo

  Royal Maxim Palace Kempinski proudly ranks among Cairo's finest luxury hotels. This 5-star gem greets you with royal elegance and indulges you with its extravagant services. If you're planning a regal event, The Excelsior, Egypt's most majestic ballroom, is the perfect venue. This splendid space provides a backdrop for memorable celebrations, adding a dash of grandeur to each event. Your luxurious dwelling is a mere 10 km from the Cairo Intl Conference Centre. And the crowning glory – Cairo International Airport is just a swift 15-minute drive away.
  • Location: First Settlement, Eastern Ring Road, New Cairo City, Cairo
  • Amenities: 3 swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle, Family rooms
  • Food Information: 5 restaurants on site, Cuisine: International, European
Accommodations Available: Twin Room, Royal Club City Room, Cabana Pool with Balcony, Grand Deluxe Pool Room – Egyptians and Residents Only, Royal Club Pool Room, Royal Suite, Maxim Suite.

Triumph Luxury Hotel

  Situated in Block 19 opposite Katamyia Heights in the 5th settlement, and a mere 14 km from the bustling City Stars, the Triumph Luxury Hotel proudly ranks among Cairo’s finest luxury accommodations. Upon entry, the hotel’s splendor welcomes you, complemented by an ATM and a dedicated concierge service. Be it the early hours or dusk, the 24-hour reception is at your service. For the travel-weary, the Cairo Intl Conference Centre is conveniently located just 17 km away, offering comfort amidst opulence. And for those intrigued by history, the renowned Al-Azhar Mosque is a mere 20 km journey.
  • Location: Block 19 in front of Katamyia Heights 5th settlement, New Cairo City, Cairo.
  • Amenities: 2 swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle, and Family rooms.
  • Food Information: 5 restaurants on site. Cuisine: African, American,  Argentinian, Italian, Mediterranean, Mexican, Middle Eastern, Moroccan, Pizza Local, Asian, International, Latin American.
  • Accommodations Available: Egyptians and Residents – Grand Deluxe City Room, Egyptians and Residents – Grand Deluxe Pool View, Family Suite, Ambassador Suite, Grand Deluxe Pool View – Twin Beds.

    Holiday Inn & Suites- Cairo Maadi

  The Holiday Inn & Suites: Cairo Maadi, nestled by the Cornish El Nil, offers breathtaking views of the iconic Giza Pyramids and is considered one of the crown jewels among Cairo’s best luxury hotels. This establishment is more than just a hotel; it’s a portal to luxury. Ideally located a short drive from the ancient world’s wonders, the Holiday Inn Cairo Maadi Towers & Casino provides an enticing mix of business and leisure. Whether your visit is for business or pleasure, you’ll be greeted with a range of luxurious amenities that redefine sophistication. With impeccable service and top-tier facilities, this hotel encapsulates the essence of Cairo’s finest luxury hotels.

The Westin Cairo Golf Resort & Spa

  The Westin Cairo Golf Resort & Spa, a 5-star jewel, is nestled in Road 90, New Cairo City, Katameya Dunes, one of Cairo’s most upscale neighborhoods. This establishment is not just a hotel; it’s an experience. Envision waking up in one of their 135 rooms or 19 suites, with views of the tranquil gardens, the welcoming pool, or the verdant expanse of the 27-hole championship golf course. Proudly bearing its title and one of the Luxury Hotels in Egypt, The Westin Cairo Golf Resort & Spa embodies luxury in its rooms, leisure facilities, and everything else. Whether you’re a guest or a local seeking a staycation, this establishment promises a luxurious getaway in Cairo’s heart.
  • Location: Road 90, New Cairo City, Katameya Dunes, New Cairo City, Cairo
  • Amenities: 2 swimming pools, Free WiFi, Airport shuttle, Family rooms
  • Food Information: 2 restaurants on site
  • Room type offered: Presidential Suite, Presidential Suite, 1 King, Sofa bed, Westin Suite, 1 Bedroom Suite, 1 King, Resort view, Poolside, Superior PoolSide Room, 1 Twin/Single Bed(s), Classic Garden View, 2 Double, Garden view.

What are the Key Factors for Choosing Cairo’s Luxury Hotels?

1. Location and Accessibility:

 The hotel’s positioning is pivotal Luxury Hotels Information .Moreover, verify the convenience of nearby transport facilities such as airports, railways, and principal highways. An advantageous locale can amplify your ease and diminish transit durations.  

2. Amenities and Services:

 Luxury hotels boast an array of superior facilities and personalized attention. Elite accommodations frequently provide bespoke services such as valet attendants and private chauffeurs; hence, assess the spectrum of amenities to suit your tastes.  

3. Room Quality and Design:

The quality of the accommodations is of paramount importance. Numerous luxury hotels also proffer room types with captivating vistas of the metropolis or renowned landmarks. A plush and chic chamber can significantly elevate your visit.

4. Reviews and Reputation:

 Guest Feedback examines the hotel’s character via guest reviews, travel portals, and digital networks. Perusing the accounts of fellow visitors can yield valuable perspectives on the establishment’s service quality, hygiene, and overall patron satisfaction. This was the main criteria of luxury 5-star hotels in Cairo.

Conclusion

In Cairo, a city where the past and present coexist, the luxury hotel landscape mirrors its dynamic character. These hotels, with their stunning Nile views and flawless service catering to your every desire, redefine luxury. Whether you’re relishing gourmet meals in upscale restaurants or relaxing with a revitalizing spa session, these hotels embody the quintessence of luxurious living in Cairo. In terms of experiencing the pinnacle of sophistication and comfort, Cairo’s finest luxury hotels seamlessly encapsulate the modern magnificence of this age-old city. Cut into the mountainside of southern Egypt, the colossal Abu Simbel Temples are one of Egypt's most spectacular treasures.  The Architecture of Abu Simbel Temples features four seated colossi of Ramesses II, the largest being 20 meters high, safeguarding the entrance. Renowned for their gigantic statues of the pharaoh, their original location was accurately recreated in the 1960s after being relocated higher due to the construction of the Aswan High Dam.

History of Abu Simbel Temple

  As the sands of time drifted, the once majestic temples faded into obscurity. The Great Temple, engulfed by a vast sand dune, receded from memory. By the 6th century BC, the sand concealed the temple's statues up to their knees, burying their grandeur and history of Abu Simbel Temple. Europeans remained oblivious to its existence until March 1813, when a Swiss researcher named Johann Ludwig Burckhardt stumbled upon the small temple and glimpsed the top frieze of the main temple.  

Where is the Abu Simbel Temple Located?

The Abu Simbel temple stands in the village of Abu Simbel in the Aswan Governorate of Upper Egypt, close to the Sudanese border.  Abu Simbel Temple Location rests on the western bank of Lake Nasser, roughly 230 km (140 mi) southwest of Aswan (about 300 km (190 mi) by road).

which pharaoh was ordered to build the Abu Simbel Temples in Aswan?

Commissioned by Pharaoh Ramesses II in the 13th century BC, they were dedicated to the ancient Egyptian gods Ptah, Amun, and himself as a form of sun deity.

Abu Simbel Sun Festival

    The sun illuminates Abu Simbel's Temple with an outstanding solar alignment during the equinoxes,  so that on February 22 and October 22 each year (Abu Simbel Sun Festival), the rising sun's rays penetrated the inner sanctuaries and illuminated three statues on the back wall, an impressive sight. As both architectural wonders and monuments to power, the Abu Simbel Temples represent the heights of New Kingdom artistic achievement and royal vanity, continuing to inspire millions of visitors today.

The Architecture of Abu Simbel Temples

  The temple's design is an amazing showcase of the grandeur of ancient Egyptian civilization. This impressive structure stands 30 meters tall and stretches 35 meters in length. As you enter, you'll be greeted by four colossal statues portraying Ramses the Great seated on a throne, towering at 20 meters (65 feet). Below these imposing figures, smaller statues illustrate Ramses defeating enemies, honoring and protecting gods and family. Upon entering, you'll find an image of Ramesses II seated on a throne, wearing the double crown of Upper and Lower Egypt. Inside, three consecutive halls span a remarkable 56 meters (185 feet). The hypostyle hall, boasting a width of 16.7 meters and a height of 18 meters, is supported by eight massive Osiris pillars, symbolizing Ramses as the ruler of the underworld Osiris and emphasizing the pharaoh's eternal nature. In the central chamber, you'll discover statues representing various gods, adorned with depictions of the pharaoh, scenes from his victory at the Battle of Kadesh in 1274 BC (marking the first recorded peace treaty in history), and more. On the façade, a row of 22 baboons with raised arms worships the rising sun. The inner sanctuary houses the four seated gods of Ramses II—Ptah (God of creation), Amun (The Creator God), and Ra (Sun God)—playing a central role in the sun festival. Not far from the great temple, the Nefertari temple, a charming architectural masterpiece, sits 100 meters northeast. Decorated with two groups of colossi separated by a large gateway, it features two statues of the queen and six statues of her husband, King Ramses II, standing at 10.5 meters (35 feet). These statues pay homage to "Hathor," the goddess of love, allure, and joy, the sky falcon Horus, and Maat, the goddess of Justice, among others.

The Love-Infused Wonders of Abu Simbel’s Small Temple:

The enchanting Small Temple of Abu Simbel, a monument to love and devotion, is nestled just 100 meters northeast of the grand temple of Ramesses II. This sacred site honors the divine goddess Hathor and the esteemed queen Nefertari, Ramesses II’s beloved consort. Remarkably, it stands as only the second instance in the storied annals of ancient Egypt where a temple is consecrated to a queen, echoing the earlier tribute by Akhenaten to his cherished royal wife, Nefertiti. As you approach, be captivated by the temple’s rock-hewn facade, graced by two majestic groups of colossal statues, divided by a grand entranceway. Towering over 10 meters tall, these impressive effigies depict the regal couple—Ramesses II and Nefertari. Flanking the gateway, witness the dual representations of the pharaoh: to the south, adorned with the pure white crown of Upper Egypt, and to the north, with the illustrious double crown, both complemented by the elegant figures of the queen.   Burckhardt shared his astounding find with Italian explorer Giovanni Belzoni, who ventured to the site but struggled to unearth an entryway into the temple. Undeterred from revealing the history of Abu Simbel Temple, Belzoni returned in 1817 and triumphantly achieved access to the enigmatic complex. A vivid account of the temples, accompanied by contemporary line drawings, can be found in Edward William Lane's Description of Egypt (1825–1828).   The tale of Abu Simbel is one of loss and rediscovery, where time's relentless march shrouded ancient marvels in oblivion. Yet, through the tenacity of explorers and the pages of historical accounts, the splendor of these temples was resurrected, allowing us to peer into the secrets of a bygone era.

The Relocation of Abu Simbel Temples

 

Why Was Abu Simbel Temple in Aswan Relocated in The 1960s?

 The Relocation of Abu Simbel Temples In 1959, was an urgent mission that unfolded as the rising waters of the Nile threatened the ancient relics of Nubia. The Aswan High Dam's construction posed a grave danger to this southernmost remnant of a glorious civilization. A global campaign supported by UNESCO mobilized to rescue the history of Abu Simbel Temple.   In 1964, a daring team of archaeologists, engineers, and skilled operators embarked on an unprecedented endeavor. With a budget of $40 million (equivalent to $377.42 million today), they set out to salvage the magnificent Abu Simbel temples.   Over four arduous years, an extraordinary feat unfolded. Piece by colossal piece, some weighing up to 30 tons (averaging 20 tons), the temples were meticulously cut, dismantled, and raised to safety. This audacious undertaking pushed the boundaries of archaeology, showcasing the ingenuity of the human spirit.  

Where Did They Move Abu Simbel Temple From?

The Relocation of Abu Simbel Temples and The new site, carefully chosen 65 meters higher and 200 meters back from the river, became a sanctuary for these ancient wonders. Defying the relentless flow of the Nile, the Abu Simbel temples proudly stood in their new home. The rescue of Abu Simbel exemplifies the unwavering commitment to preserving our shared human heritage. It is a testament to the dedication of those who refused to let the history of Abu Simbel Temple be lost to time. This remarkable achievement ensures that future generations can continue to marvel at the splendor of a bygone era.

How do you get to Abu Simbel Temple in Aswan?

  If you're interested in visiting the Abu Simbel Temple Location, you have two options: take a day trip from Aswan or see during a flight between Cairo and Aswan. There are three ways to reach Abu Simbel: roundtrip flight from Aswan, land from Aswan, or between Cairo and Aswan. Please let me know if you require additional help; I hope this information has been helpful.

What are the best days to visit Abu Simbel Temple in Aswan?

  The best months to visit Abu Simbel are January, February, and December when the weather is mildly warm and pleasantly cool. February 22 is the Abu Simbel Sun Festival, attracting thousands of tourists, so be prepared for large crowds. Make reservations several months in advance since these months are the busiest season for tourism, with higher prices for hotels and airfare.

Ben Ezra Synagogue History

Located in the Fustat area of Old Cairo, Egypt, the Ben Ezra Synagogue, also known as the El-Geniza Synagogue, stands as a significant historical site. In Hebrew, it’s known as בית כנסת בן עזרא, and in Arabic, it’s referred to as معبد بن عزرا. Local legends suggest that this is the very place where Moses was discovered as an infant. Sun Pyramids Tours, 1970, the most innovative travel agency in Egypt, is inviting you to embark on a remarkable journey through Coptic Cairo and Ben Ezra Synagogue. Experience the splendor of Coptic Cairo, where majestic churches and the Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ's sacred sites. The Ben Ezra Synagogue, once a vibrant center for Jewish festivities, congregations, and devotions in Egypt, has evolved into a point of interest for tourists following the departure of the majority of the Jewish community in the 1950s.  

When was Ben Ezra Sanygouge established? Origins The exact date of the establishment of the Ben Ezra Synagogue remains uncertain. However, documents discovered in the genizah suggest that it was likely established before 882 CE, possibly during the pre-Islamic era.

In 882, a church and its surrounding property were sold by the patriarch of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria to a Jewish group. Some scholars in the 19th century speculated that this transaction marked the birth of Ben Ezra. However, the purchasers were adherents of the Talmudic Academies in Babylonia, while Ben Ezra was a congregation that followed the teachings of the competing Talmudic Academies in Syria Palaestina. Contemporary scholars concur that the synagogue sold in 882 was a different one.   The location of the Synagogue is also steeped in biblical lore, believed to be the very spot where the Pharaoh’s wife discovered and rescued baby Moses from his river-bound basket.

Ben Ezra Synagogue Facts

  In the 19th century, a remarkable discovery was made in the synagogue’s genizah, or storage room. A wealth of Hebrew, Aramaic, and Judeo-Arabic manuscripts, and more than 250,000 historic papers, both secular and sacred, that had been lost and stored away were found, turning the synagogue into a treasure trove of historical documents.   The refurbishment process involved careful architectural conservation efforts on the walls and ceiling, as well as an overhaul of the lighting system, according to the statement.   Boasting an impressive array of books and documents that offer a glimpse into the societal life of Egyptian Jewish communities, the Ben Ezra Synagogue is of considerable significance in the study of modern Jewish history.

When was Discovered in Ben Ezra Synagogue

Jacob Saphir, a Romanian-born Jew who moved to Ottoman Palestine during his childhood, later became a rabbi. In 1859, he embarked on a global journey to fundraise for the restoration of Jerusalem’s Hurva Synagogue, which had been demolished by authorities in 1721. Saphir was the first to acknowledge the historical importance of the geniza at Ben Ezra Synagogue, a fact he documented in a book published in 1874. The first European to access the geniza was Jewish book collector Elkan Nathan Adler in 1888, who acquired approximately 25,000 documents. During the synagogue’s reconstruction from 1889 to 1892, the documents were piled up in the open. Count Riamo d’Hulst, an Egyptologist, examined some of these documents during this period. In December 1896, Solomon Schechter, a Cambridge University instructor who later became a renowned American rabbi, initiated the first thorough scholarly study of the geniza documents. He also arranged for the remaining documents to be transferred from Cairo to various university libraries.

Ben Ezra Synagogue Architecture

  The synagogue’s doors were officially opened by Egypt Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly on September 2023, marking the completion of a decade-long restoration project, as reported by the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities (MOTA). The latest refurbishment was carried out by the Drop of Milk Association, an entity dedicated to the preservation of Egypt’s Jewish heritage. The restoration involved protective treatments for the ceilings and stones, as well as insulation provision. In recent years, Egypt’s MOTA has undertaken several conservation projects and worked tirelessly to restore numerous historical buildings.

Abydoss has emerged as a significant archaeological treasure in Egypt. It is home to the royal burial ground from the pre-dynastic era, which has unveiled intriguing connections with Sumeria. Additionally, it houses the Osireion, a mysterious subterranean chamber linked to the Nile, constructed from massive blocks. The architectural style of these blocks is only paralleled by the Valley temple at Giza. Later, the temple of Seti I from the Sixth Dynasty, which undoubtedly originates from an earlier period, was constructed atop this site.

Where is the Abydos Temple located, and how to get there?

The Abydos Temple is situated in the town of Abydos, which was once a prominent sacred city and a necropolis for the earliest Egyptian royalty. Abydos was also a pilgrimage hub for worshipping Osiris, the god of the afterlife, who was thought to be buried there. To reach Abydos from Luxor, you can take a private car or a taxi, which will take approximately two and a half hours. Alternatively, you can join a guided tour that includes transportation and entrance fees with Sun Pyramids Tours. Contact Us for more information. You can also combine your visit to Abydos with another nearby temple, such as Dendera or Karnak.  

  1. The Temple of Seti I (1,307-1,291 BC)

(The house of millions of years) It is considered to have been built towards the end of Seti's reign.   Seti I, the second king of the 19th Dynasty, was the son of Ramesses I and Queen Sitre. He reconciled with the Hittites, who were becoming the most powerful state in the region. Seti I and his heir, Ramesses II, campaigned against Kadesh. In Karnak, he completed his father's plan by converting the court between the second and third towers into a vast hypostyle hall. He built his vast mortuary complex at Abydos.    The renowned structure that stands today is often referred to as the Grand Temple of Abydos. The elevated reliefs in this splendid Temple are among the finest in all of Egypt. This Temple boasts a unique design, resembling an inverted "L." It also houses the most comprehensive lists of Kings and Gods. The Temple houses seven sanctuaries dedicated to 7 Gods: Osiris, Isis, Horus, Amon Ra, Ra HorAkhty, Ptah, and Seti I as a deified King. In this Temple, one can find the best-preserved painted reliefs and texts from the 18th Dynasty.   Seven chapels were constructed for the worship of the pharaoh and primary deities. At the rear of the Temple is a mysterious structure known as The Osirion, believed to be associated with the worship of Osiris, and likely from those chambers extended the grand Hypogeum for the celebration of the Osiris mysteries, constructed by Merenptah.   The Temple of Seti I is also gaining a reputation for its unique carvings discovered on one of its ceiling beams.     These engravings have garnered considerable interest in the past due to their striking resemblance to contemporary vehicles. However, it’s been proposed that they might be the result of superimposed hieroglyphs, which, despite their rarity, seem plausible when examining the rest of the beam.     The construction of Seti I’s Temple occurred significantly later than the Osireion : It’s believed that Seti I was guided to construct at this site and that he adjusted the temple’s direction upon discovering the Osireion. However, the alignment of the two temples suggests that he likely knew about the Osireion’s existence when he initiated the construction of his temple.

The Osireion (Strabo's Well, The Fountain of Abydoss)

  When Seti-I initiated the quest for a site for his Temple, he was guided to a spot north of Luxor in the Nile River’s curve. Here, he started excavating the foundation for his Temple. During this process, he stumbled upon the Osireion, the ancient temple of Osiris. Whether he was aware of the Osireion’s existence remains a mystery, but upon encountering this ancient temple in his new temple’s path, he redirected his new temple to the left. This temple is the only one in Egypt that takes an ‘L’ turn. The structure has notable architectural disparities from the temple above and is presumed to be considerably older. It bears several resemblances to the 'Valley Temple' at Giza, which is also acknowledged as an early-dynasty edifice. Pertaining to this matter, it may be noteworthy that the temple Osireion is consecrated to Osiris, while the 'Valley temple' at Giza is linked to Isis. As of now, we lack any clues regarding the construction date. However, the design, the magnitude of the materials, and the total lack of ornamentation all suggest a very ancient origin. Until now, the so-called Sphinx temple at Gizeh has always been regarded as one of Egypt’s oldest structures. It is contemporaneous with the pyramid of Chefren… Given its similar composition but much larger materials, the Abydos reservoir exhibits an even more archaic character, and it wouldn’t be surprising if this turned out to be Egypt’s oldest structure.

Who was Dorothy Eady (Omm Sety), and what was her connection to the Abydos Temple?

  One of the most fascinating stories about the Abydos Temple is that of Dorothy Eady (1904 – 1981), also recognized as Omm Sety or Om Seti, who was a British custodian of antiques and a folklorist. She served as the guardian of the Abydos Temple of Seti I and worked as a draughtswoman for the Department of Egyptian Antiquities. She gained fame for her conviction that she had been a priestess in ancient Egypt in a past life and for her extensive historical research conducted at Abydos. Her life and contributions have been the focus of numerous articles, TV documentaries, and biographical works.   According to John A. Wilson, the late head of the Oriental Institute and regarded as the “dean of American Egyptology” by his peers, believed that Omm Sety merited recognition as “a responsible scholar.” She served as a resource for contemporary scholarship aiming to comprehend how traditional ancient religious customs have endured into the present day, manifesting as “folk customs” observed by modern Egyptian Copts and Muslims. Unlike others who professed to be reincarnated entities from ancient Egypt, she was accorded respect by Egyptologists. While none publicly endorsed the phenomena she described, none questioned her honesty, and many have utilized her insights on past and present Egypt as credible source material.

Ramesses II Temple

  The neighboring temple of Ramesses II, although smaller and simpler in design, boasted a remarkable historical series of scenes on its exterior that celebrated his accomplishments, with the lower parts still intact. The temple’s exterior was adorned with depictions of the Battle of Kadesh. A list of pharaohs, akin to that of Seti I, once stood here; however, the fragments were acquired by the French consul and sold to the British Museum. The top two rows of the list feature the names of the kings, while the third row repeats Ramesses II’s throne name.  

What are the opening hours of The Abydos Temple

The opening hours of The Abydos Temple are:
  • Daily from 7 AM to 6 PM

Welcome to the enchanting world of Egypt, a captivating destination that boasts an illustrious history and magnificent civilization. know The Must be Visited Cities in Egypt Immerse yourself in the abundance of monumental wonders that form the very essence of Egyptian tourism. From the majestic pyramids to the tranquil beaches, the mystical Nile River cruise to the breathtaking oases and resorts, Egypt has it all. When you’re considering a holiday in Egypt, it’s crucial to familiarize yourself with the primary cities that attract tourists. Let us introduce you to the highlights: Let Sun Pyramids Tours guide you through these mesmerizing destinations, ensuring an unforgettable journey through Egypt's Tourist Attractions. Join us as we uncover the secrets of Aswan, dive into the wonders of Sharm El-Sheikh and Hurghada, and indulge in the healing embrace of Siwa Oasis. Your Egyptian adventure awaits.

Cairo, Egypt’s Vibrant Capital, a Cultural, Religious, and Architectural Treasure Trove?

  Egypt’s vibrant capital is a treasure trove of cultural, religious, architectural, and culinary heritage. Explore the grand Egyptian Museum, witness the splendor of the Saladin Citadel, and marvel at architectural gems like the Mohammed Ali Mosque and the twin mosques of Sultan Hassan and El-Refai. Don't forget to wander through the historic Khan Al-Khalili bazaar and discover the captivating Muizz Street, a living testament to Egypt's past.

Archeological Areas:

Founded by the Pharaohs and originally known as Heliopolis, our city has been a melting pot of cultures and religions, each leaving behind a rich tapestry of tales and treasures. Beyond the iconic pyramids of Giza that grace the city’s periphery, the Egyptian Museum stands as a beacon for those yearning to traverse through Egypt’s chronological history. The museum is a treasure trove, boasting an array of artifacts, relics, and remnants from the Egyptian civilization. It is here that you will find:

 

  • Egyptian Museum

  • Solar Boat Museum

  • Ancient City of Memphis

  • Pyramid of Djoser

  • Dahshur Necropolis

  • Necropolis of Saqqara

  Coptic Cairo: This historic district contains some of Cairo's most senior and significant religious sites. It is also known as old Cairo, home to many Christian churches and monasteries. You can visit the Hanging Church, built on top of an ancient Roman gatehouse with a wooden roof resembling Noah's ark. You can also see the Church of St. Sergius and Bacchus, which is said to be constructed on the spot where Joseph, Mary, and Jesus stayed during their flight to Egypt.  

  • Ben Ezra Synagogue

  • Church of St Sergius & Bacchus

  • Hanging Church in Cairo

Islamic Cairo:

The heart of the city, Islamic Cairo, predates the architectural marvel that is Downtown, nestled amidst the modern cityscape and extending towards the majestic pyramids of Giza. The Fatimid dynasty, upon their ascension to power in 969 BC, established a new capital to the north of the existing city. This new city emerged as the nerve center of the caliphate’s administration. It is home to:  

  • Bayt Al Suhaymi in Cairo

  • Amr Ibn Al-Aas Mosque

  • Al-Hakim Mosque

  • Al Rifa’i Mosque

  • Al Aqmar Mosque

  • Muizz Street

  • Mosque of Sultan Hassan

  • Mosque of Ibn Tulun

  • Saladin Citadel in Cairo

  • Mosque of Muhammad Ali

  • Al Azhar Mosque

  • Wekalet El Ghouri

  • Khan el Khalili Bazaar

Giza, Egypt

  Giza, a city that’s just a short distance away and one of the Must be Visited Cities in Egypt, is the proud host of the globally renowned Giza Pyramids and the mysterious Sphinx. Immerse yourself in the captivating history of Saqqara, where the Step Pyramid of King Djoser stands as a symbol of ancient architectural ingenuity. Giza Attractions:  

  • Grand Egyptian Museum

  • Great Sphinx of Giza

  • Pyramid of Menkaure

  • Pyramid of Khafre

  • Great Pyramid of Cheops

  • Giza Necropolis

Alexandria, Egypt’s Bride of the Mediterranean, a Must-Visit Destination

 

Venture north to Alexandria, the beautiful bride of the Mediterranean. Relax on its stunning beaches, delve into its rich history at the Citadel of Qaitbay and the catacombs of Kom El-Shoqafa, and marvel at landmarks like Pompey's Pillar and the Roman Theater. Be sure to visit the modern marvel that is the new Library of Alexandria, a haven for knowledge and cultural exploration. Alexandria Attractions: Alexandria, Egypt’s second-largest city, graces the Mediterranean coast, nestled on the western edge of the Nile Delta. As the oldest city in Egypt with continuous habitation, Alexandria is a testament to the sands of time. While its glory days may be in the past, the city continues to captivate visitors with its wealth of monuments, particularly those hailing from the Greek and Roman eras. It is home to:

  • Library of Alexandria

  • Catacombs of Kom El Shoqafa

  • Rosetta Egypt

  • PompePompey’sar

  • Montazah Palace

  • The Citadel of Qaitbay

 What Inspiring Treasures Can You Discover in Luxor, Egypt

  Journey to Luxor, a city brimming with awe-inspiring treasures. Unleash your sense of wonder at the Karnak Temples and the Temple of Luxor. Explore the mortuary temple of Queen Hatshepsut and immerse yourself in the mysteries of the royal tombs in the Valley of the Kings. Luxor's museums and hot-air balloon rides offer additional delights to enhance your experience.

And what better way to embrace the essence of Egypt than through a magical Nile River cruise? Sail on a felucca, a traditional boat, for a brief yet memorable voyage. Alternatively, indulge in a more extended cruise, allowing you to bask in the timeless beauty of the Nile. Luxor Attractions: Luxor, often referred to as “the world’s largest open-air museum,” is one of Egypt’s premier cities and a globally renowned tourist destination. Nestled on the eastern bank of the Nile, Luxor is a treasure trove of ancient Egyptian history, as attested by numerous tourism and historical organizations. It is home to:

  • Valley of the Kings

  • Tombs of The Nobles

  • The Ramesseum

  • Temple of Dendera

  • Temple of Abydos

  • Luxor Temple

  • Luxor Museum

  • Luxor City

  • Karnak Temple

  • Hatshepsut Temple

  • Colossi of Memnon

Aswan, Egypt’s

  Aswan, one of the Must be Visited Cities in Egypt, is the proud host of the globally renowned Giza Pyramids. The mysterious Sphina, a serene city located south of Luxor in Upper Egypt, offers a delightful contrast to bustling urban life. Embrace the tranquility of its spectacular nature and immerse yourself in its peaceful atmosphere.

The magnificent Temple of Abu Simbel stands as the crown jewel of Aswan. Carved into a large rock by the legendary King Ramses II, this temple was meticulously relocated to save it from the rising waters of the High Dam. A Nile cruise on Lake Nasser behind the dam will reveal more of the Nubian monuments that were rescued and relocated. Aswan Attractions:

Aswan, nestled on the eastern bank of the Nile, is a magnet for tourists, drawn by its wealth of ancient monuments and statues that narrate the tale of a grand civilization. Visitors flock here to delve into the might of the Egyptian pharaohs and their monumental legacy that continues to be studied today. Witness the echoes of centuries-old conflicts over land and influence between two cultures. It is home to:

  • Nubian Museum

  • Tombs of Nobles Aswan

  • Temple of Kom Ombo

  • Temple of Edfu

  • Unfinished Obelisk

  • Elephantine Island

  • Temple of Philae

  • Aswan High Dam

  • Abu Simbel Temple

 What Makes Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt’s Prominent Tourist Destination

  Sharm El-Sheikh, one of the most famous Egyptian tourist attractions and a prominent tourist destination, captivates visitors with its stunning Red Sea coastline. Dive into the crystal-clear waters teeming with vibrant marine life as scuba diving takes center stage. Explore the colorful coral reefs and encounter an array of captivating sea creatures. For a more leisurely experience, embark on a private sea cruise, where relaxation, snorkeling, and dolphin sightings await. Indulge in a delightful shopping excursion at the old market and Soho Square, where you can find unique gifts and souvenirs. Discover the allure of Sharm El-Sheikh with our top attractions:
  1. Ras Mohammed National Park: A must-visit for its stunning beaches, mangrove forest, and saltwater lake. Don’t miss the breathtaking view from Shark Cliff Upper Observatory.
  2. Naama Bay: The heart of resort life, boasting a white-sand beach lined with high-end resorts. Relax on sun loungers or explore the numerous eateries and shops.
  3. Ras Um Sid Beach: Perfect for relaxation and snorkeling. Its offshore coral reef is a haven for marine life, making it a favorite among divers.
  4. Sharm Old Market: Experience the local culture at this bustling bazaar, offering a variety of traditional goods and eateries.
  5. The Blue Hole: Sinai’s most famous dive site. Its deep blue waters teem with marine life, offering an unforgettable diving experience.
Join us and immerse yourself in the captivating beauty of Sharm El-Sheikh!

Why is Hurghada, Egypt’s, a Must-Visit Destination on the Red Sea’s Western Coast

  Hurghada, once a humble fishing village, has blossomed into a thriving tourist resort on the Red Sea's western coast. Sun-drenched beaches and world-class diving centers beckon, inviting you to explore the wonders beneath the waves. Embark on an exhilarating safari tour to discover the desert's hidden gems and experience the thrill of off-road adventures. Immerse yourself in the serene beauty of Hurghada, where you can find tranquility through meditation, bask in the glow of golden beaches, and engage in a plethora of water sports, including snorkeling. Hurghada also offers thrilling desert adventures, with Jeep excursions and quad biking experiences that are sure to get your adrenaline pumping. It’s no wonder that many travelers prefer the coastal charm of Hurghada over traditional desert cities for their vacation. Experience the best of both worlds with these attractions in Hurghada:

  • Giftun Islands

  • The Blue Hole

  • Perfect for relaxation and snorkeling

  • Experience the local culture at this bustling bazaar

  • Hurghada City Centre and Corniche

  • Hurghada Markets and Souks

  • Marine Museum and Aquarium

  • Shipwreck Diving Sites

What Natural Sanctuary and Healing Properties Can You Find in Siwa Oasis, Egypt’s Western Region

  Siwa Oasis, nestled in Egypt's western region, offers a natural sanctuary renowned for its healing properties. Indulge in the therapeutic hot springs, which are believed to possess natural remedies for various ailments. Dive into Cleopatra's Bath, named after the legendary queen herself, and immerse yourself in the rejuvenating waters. The oasis also boasts ancient monuments and castles that whisper tales of a bygone era. If you’re planning a trip to Siwa, Don’t miss out on the rich cultural tapestry that awaits you. Begin your exploration at the Siwa House Museum, a window into the lives of the Siwan people. Nestled within a quintessential Siwan mud-brick abode, the museum showcases the vibrant history, artisanal crafts, and enduring traditions of the locale.

Siwa Attractions:

  • Shali Fortress

  • The Temple of the Oracle

  • Siwa Salt Lakes

  • Gebel Al Muwata – Mountain of the Dead

  • The Temple of Amon

Egypt is a destination for all seasons, where you can experience the wonders of ancient and modern times. But when is the best time to visit this captivating country? It depends on what you’re looking for. If you want to enjoy the sun and the sand, winter is the Best Time to Visit Egypt. From December to February, you can unwind on the beaches, admire the pyramids of Giza, and cruise on the Nile. The weather is mild and cozy, making it perfect for outdoor activities. If you want to avoid the heat and the crowds, spring and autumn are the best seasons to visit Egypt. From March to May and from September to November, you can explore the temples and tombs at your own pace and enjoy the moderate temperatures. Egypt is a land of endless possibilities, where you can discover its rich history and culture, its stunning nature and wildlife, and its friendly and hospitable people. Whatever season you choose, you’ll find something to suit your taste and budget.

Best Time for sightseeing in cooler temperatures

October - February

  How do you enjoy Egypt’s ancient and natural attractions in the coolest season? The Perfect Time to Discover and Relax In the Northern European winter, many travelers (and tour groups) flee the gloomy skies back home to enjoy the beaches of Sharm el-Sheikh and the Red Sea coast this time of year, is the Best time to travel to Egypt. You’ll experience pleasant weather across most of the country, although in Cairo and Alexandria, expect some rain. Suppose you’re here to explore Luxor’s abundance of Pharaonic wonders. In that case, winter brings clear skies and cozy daytime temperatures to make long days of wandering around ancient ruins a delight rather than a challenge. This is also the  Best time to travel to Egypt and the most popular season to venture into the Sinai or the Western Desert for outdoor adventures (from hiking to camel trekking) or to soak up the winter sun while learning to dive in South Sinai and along the Red Sea coast. Divers should note that sea conditions can be rough on boat dives around December, but shore dives are usually fine. In Cairo, the mild weather makes November an excellent time for long walks to admire the capital’s madrassas and mosques. Be aware it will be chillier than you might think (especially after dark), so you also need to pack something warm. Finally, be ready to pay more for accommodation during the winter high season, especially around Christmas and New Year.

Best Time for warm temperatures and gentle breezes

March - May, September - early October

  How do you experience Egypt’s highlights with fewer crowds and more comfort? Visiting Egypt during the shoulder season can give you the best of both worlds. Major monuments are less crowded, and you can often find a good deal on accommodation. Daytime temperatures can be scorching in May and September, so shoulder season travelers who prefer cooler weather (and families with young children) should opt for March, April, or October instead. The weather is usually comfortable, so you can enjoy a full day outside from late September to October. This is Egypt’s best travel season. It’s also a good time for diving. The light along the Nile is soft and clear, ideal for photography in Luxor and Aswan. In the Western Desert oases, the date harvest is in full swing. In April, the khamsin can still be a problem, but when it’s not blowing, this is a near-perfect and Best time to travel to Egypt. The warmer evenings make it especially good for overnight felucca trips from Aswan and camping in the White Desert. May is usually a good time for package deals to resorts like Sharm el-Sheikh, Hurghada, El Gouna, and Marsa Alam.

The best time to visit for the start of summer

June: August

  How do you enjoy Egypt’s ancient wonders and dive paradise in the hottest season?

The weather becomes scorching as the average high temperature reaches 108°F (42°C). Luxor’s temples and tombs open at 6 am, so you can still beat the heat by being an early bird.

You may hear a joking “Welcome to Alaska!” in Aswan. Unless you’re very resilient, it’s better to avoid the Western Desert. Summer is when avid divers flock to Sharm el-Sheikh and the Red Sea coast. They don’t mind the baking heat on land, as they enjoy the calm, warm sea conditions and excellent underwater visibility. You can dive in Egypt all year round, though. Just to break the low season rule, summer is the peak domestic holiday period along the Mediterranean coast, as half of Cairo escapes to the beach. Yes, it’s still hot in Alexandria, but at least there’s a breeze.

How do you travel during Ramadan in Egypt?

  When to Travel to Egypt, the dates for Ramadan (the month when Muslims fast during daylight hours) vary every year as the Islamic calendar follows the lunar cycle.   If you're traveling during Ramadan, keep in mind that tourist sites, as well as most shops and services, have shorter hours, and many non-tourist-oriented restaurants and cafes only open after sunset.

Best Times to Visit Egypt for a Nile Cruise

 

How do you choose the best time to experience Egypt’s river of life?

Embarking on a Nile cruise, primarily between Luxor and Aswan, offers an unparalleled opportunity to explore Egypt, often referred to as “the cradle of civilization.” The optimal time for a Nile Cruise for the most pleasant experience is during the mild season, which spans from December to February. If you’re considering a family vacation to Egypt during the festive period of Christmas and New Year, a Nile cruise can provide an unforgettable experience and a celebratory ambiance. You’ll get to partake in the festivities with the crew, fellow vacationers, and your family. Taking into account both the climate and budget considerations, the most favorable times for a Nile Cruise are during the warm seasons, from March to April and October to November. These periods offer fewer crowds, more affordable prices compared to the peak season, and comfortable temperatures for outdoor exploration. If your travel plans include the peak season, it’s recommended to secure your flight and hotel bookings at least six months in advance. This helps avoid potential stress related to temporary price hikes and sold-out rooms or seats. Opt for a journey with Sun Pyramids for a seamless, personalized tour, regardless of your travel dates.

Conclusion

Egypt has a hot and dry climate, with mild winters and scorching summers. The best time to visit Egypt is from October to April when the weather is more relaxed and comfortable. Consider steering clear of the peak months of December and January, when costs escalate and crowds swell. The summer months of May to September are scorching and dry. However, if you don’t mind the heat, you can find cheaper deals and fewer tourists during this time.

Alexandria City History

  Alexandria, a city steeped in history and mystique, has long held a prominent place in the development of religious and philosophical thought. From its early days as a center of Hellenistic culture to its later role as a crucible for religious and intellectual exchange, Alexandria has left an indelible mark on global beliefs. This article explores the city's profound influence on Hellenism, Judaism, early Christianity, and Islam, shedding light on its enigmatic legacy. Sun Pyramids Tours, 1970, the most innovative travel agency in Egypt, is inviting you to visit Alexandria and promising you an unforgettable Christian Monuments exploration to the most sacred and spiritual places all over Egypt. Contact us now, or Continue the article to find more helpful knowledge and packages. Before we delve into the depths of Alexandrian history, it must be noted that this article is not meant to be a narration of ordinary historical events that take place on the coasts of this Mediterranean city. And if you notice that at the beginning of the article, you must know that this historical narration is just an introduction to explain the mysterious and enigmatic influences of this Ancient city on the world's ideas and beliefs.  

Foundation and Medieval growth

  Alexandria, founded by Alexander the Great in 332 BCE, served as the capital of his new Egyptian territory and a strategic naval base. Its location, with access to abundant water and a natural harbor provided by the island of Pharos, made it an ideal choice.   Under the Ptolemies, Alexandria experienced a golden age, merging ancient Greek and Egyptian religions in the cult of Serapis. Within a century, Alexandria became a prominent Mediterranean city and a hub of Greek scholarship and science. The Mouseion, a renowned research institute founded by the Ptolemies, attracted notable scholars like Euclid, Archimedes, and Ptolemy.   Alexandria boasted a celebrated library that housed numerous Greek texts, while a subsidiary library was established at the temple of Serapis. Unfortunately, the main library was destroyed during a civil war under Roman emperor Aurelian in the late 3rd century CE.   The city also hosted a significant Jewish community and played a vital role in Jewish learning. The translation of the Old Testament into Greek, known as the Septuagint, was produced in Alexandria. However, the diverse ethnic and religious groups present in the city led to frequent interethnic strife during this era.

Alexandria City At Roman and Byzantine periods

  During the Roman and Byzantine eras, as the Ptolemies’ power waned in the 2nd and 1st centuries BCE, Rome ascended to prominence. Alexandria became a pivotal player in the political machinations that led to the formation of the Roman Empire. Cleopatra, the final Ptolemaic ruler, famously wooed Julius Caesar in Alexandria and professed to have given birth to his child. Despite her efforts to revive the Ptolemaic dynasty, Caesar’s murder and her ill-fated backing of Mark Antony against Caesar’s grandnephew, Octavian, thwarted her plans. In 30 BCE, Octavian, who later became Emperor Augustus, officially annexed Alexandria and Egypt into the Roman Empire. The city was strategically important as it controlled access to Egypt’s grain reserves, which Rome increasingly depended on.

Alexandria in Islamic period

  Islamic period is While Alexandria capitulated to the Muslim Arab expansion without resistance, the conquest led to a significant departure of the Greek population’s leading elements. From then on, apart from a brief interlude in 645 when the Byzantine fleet temporarily retook the city, Alexandria’s fate was intertwined with the political and cultural developments in Islam. Alexandria was politically overshadowed by the new Arab capital at Al-Fusṭāṭ (later absorbed into the modern capital, Cairo); the Coptic Patriarchate was moved there from Alexandria in the 11th century. However, Alexandria continued to prosper as a trading hub, mainly for textiles and luxury goods, as Arab influence extended westward through North Africa and into Europe. The city held importance as a naval base, particularly under the Fāṭimids and the Mamlūks, but it had already begun to reduce in size, reflecting its new, less grandiose status. The Arab walls, which were reconstructed in the 13th and 14th centuries and dismantled in the 19th century, enclosed an area that was less than half of the Greco-Roman city’s expanse.

Evolution of the modern city

While the city’s historical landmarks are a crucial draw, Alexandria’s stunning contemporary side is something tourists will swiftly become enamored with. From the newly built Bibliotheca Alexandrina (a library and cultural hub that also serves as an interactive tribute to the vanished “Great Library”) to the lively downtown area and Corniche waterfront district, there’s a plethora of sights to captivate visitors. As you journey through present-day Alexandria, make sure to try the fresh seafood (a trip to the Alexandria Fish Market comes highly recommended), embark on a boat excursion on the River Nile, and explore the central Souq Ibrahimiyya; it might not be as bustling as the markets in Cairo, but it’s certainly worth a visit!  

Alexandria’s Enigmatic Influence on Global Beliefs

 

  1. Gnosticism

In the ancient world, Alexandria, Egypt, served as a significant hub for cultural exchange and learning, contributing notably to the evolution of Gnosticism. This religious and philosophical movement, which surfaced during the early Christian era, drew from a broad spectrum of traditions and ideas, including Egyptian mysticism and Greek philosophy. In Alexandria, Platonic and Neoplatonic philosophies, which were widespread in the city, influenced the Gnostics. They also engaged with the local Jewish and Christian communities, enabling them to integrate aspects of these traditions into their own doctrines. The Gnostics were recognized for their focus on spiritual knowledge (gnosis) and the concept that the physical world is inherently defective, with salvation attainable through the acquisition of this knowledge. These notions were partially shaped by the Gnostics’ exposure to Alexandria’s diverse intellectual and spiritual customs.  

  1. Hermatism

    Hermeticism is often discussed within the context of Alexandria, a city of great significance in the classical world and a hub for various philosophical and spiritual traditions. Alexandria, one of the most bustling cities in classical Egypt, was renowned for its Library and educational institutions.
Gilles Quispel, in his preface to Salaman’s Way of Hermes, confirms the existence of a secret society in Alexandria, similar to a Masonic lodge, before and after the dawn of the Christian era. This group, referring to themselves as ‘brethren,’ underwent a spiritual baptism as part of their initiation, exchanged a sacred kiss, partook in a sacred meal, and studied Hermetic writings for spiritual growth. Festugière, in Hermétisme et mystique païenne, refers to Alexandria as the “birthplace of Hermetism.” Similarly, Garth Fowden, in The Egyptian Hermes, mentions the Hermetists’ comfort in the philosophical environment of Alexandria and notes that most evidence of cultic syncretism comes from the heavily Hellenized regions of Egypt, such as Alexandria and the Fayyum.  

  1. Hellenism:

    As the intellectual heart of the Hellenistic world, Alexandria became a melting pot of Greek philosophy, science, and culture. The city's renowned Library and Museum attracted scholars from far and wide, fostering the exchange of ideas. Prominent Hellenistic philosophers like Euclid, Eratosthenes, and Ptolemy thrived in Alexandria, shaping mathematical and astronomical knowledge that would influence future generations.
 

  1. Judaism:

    Alexandria's vibrant Jewish community significantly influenced the city’s intellectual and cultural landscape. The Septuagint, a Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible, originated in Alexandria, thereby promoting the dissemination of Jewish scriptures and ideologies across the Hellenistic world. Jewish philosophers, Philo of Alexandria among them, endeavored to harmonize Jewish doctrines with Greek philosophy, contributing to the evolution of Hellenistic Jewish thought.

    5. Early Christianity: 

Alexandria became a crucible for early Christian thought and a center of theological debate. The renowned theologian Origen, known for his allegorical interpretation of scripture, taught in Alexandria and influenced Christian theology for centuries. The Alexandrian school of thought, with its emphasis on spiritual understanding and mystical interpretation, shaped the development of Christian doctrine and spirituality.  

  1. Islam:

With the advent of Islam in the 7th century, Alexandria's influence expanded once again. The city became a hub for Islamic scholarship and a gateway for the spread of Islamic teachings. Scholars like Ibn al-Haytham, known for his contributions to modern optics, emerged from Alexandria, contributing to the flourishing of Islamic intellectual and scientific advancements.

Conclusion

Alexandria's influence on global beliefs is undeniable. From the philosophical schools of Hellenism to the translation and dissemination of Jewish scriptures, the city served as a cultural crossroad where ideas merged and evolved. Its impact on early Christian theology and the subsequent development of Islamic scholarship further cemented its enigmatic legacy. Alexandria's intellectual and religious contributions continue to resonate through the centuries, reminding us of its profound influence on shaping the beliefs and ideas that have shaped our world.

An Egypt Nile Cruise is one of the famous tourist attractions in Egypt, where travelers can sail along the immortal Nile River where they can see and visit historical sites and landmarks such as Abu Simbel temples, the temples of Luxor, Karnak, and the Valley of the Kings, Sun Pyramids Tours, 1970, the most innovative travel agency in Egypt, is promising you an unforgettable Nile cruise experience and an enjoyable and entertaining vacation on board a Nile river cruise. Nile cruises can run from a few days to a week or more and generally offer full-board accommodations, amusement, and guided tours for various sites along the river. The best time to go on a Nile cruise is during the cooler months of November through February, although cruises operate year-round.

Types of Nile Cruise

    There are various types of Egypt Nile river cruises available, each offering a unique and different experience. From luxury ships to traditional feluccas, there’s a cruise for every traveler. You are the decider of what kind of experience you want to have, whether you want to have more communication with nature or feel the luxury of Las Vegas hotels while you’re boarding the Nile: Modern and Luxury Nile Cruise: These are the most expensive and exclusive options, offering spacious cabins, modern amenities, fine dining, and personalized service. Some examples are Movenpick Royal Lily, Oberoi Philae, and Sanctuary Sun Boat IV. Dahabiya Nile Cruises: These traditional wooden sailboats offer a more intimate and authentic experience of the Nile. They have fewer cabins, usually 6 to 12, and can access smaller sites that larger ships cannot. Some examples are Dahabiya Amoura, Dahabiya Judi, and Dahabiya Donia.

The Nile River Cruises By Categories

    Standard Nile Cruises offers an affordable yet comfortable journey, allowing travelers to witness the grandeur of Egypt’s civilization at dawn and dusk. It’s a perfect choice for budget-conscious explorers who want to enjoy good service without breaking the bank.   Deluxe Nile Cruises: These are more affordable than luxury cruises but still offer comfortable cabins, good facilities, and quality food. Some examples are Sonesta Star Goddess, MS Blue Shadow, and Movenpick Royal Lily. Luxury Nile Cruises: These are the most expensive and exclusive options, offering spacious cabins, modern amenities, fine dining, and personalized service. Some examples are Viking Ra, Oberoi Philae, and Sanctuary Sun Boat IV.

Define Your Budget Before Booking Nile Cruises

    Before booking your Egypt Nile cruise, it’s essential to define your budget. We offer a range of options to suit various budgets, ensuring everyone can enjoy this magical experience. Standard Nile Cruises Deluxe Nile Cruises   Luxury Nile Cruises

What Will You Visit During Nile River Cruises in Egypt?

    While the Nile River runs across the whole Egyptian country from south to north, splitting it into two banks means that a Nile cruise can reach the majority of Egyptian attractions and monuments. So, suppose you decide to start your voyage from Aswan down south Egypt to sail with the Nile water stream to the north. In that case, it means that you can see Luxor attractions like the Karnak temple complex, Luxor Temple, Ramsium, Habu city, Dendra, and Abydos temples in middle Egypt as you move through the north until you reach the Giza Plateau with its magnificent pyramids, Sphinx, and the Wadi Temple, and all the modern attractions as you reach Cairo such as the Grand Museum of Egypt, Coptic Cairo with its old churchs that some have been built by Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ himself, and for sure Islamic Cairo including historical Mosques, medieval streets and forts.   You should take care of the weather as it is getting a bit cold as you sail down to the north, so prepare yourself with windbreakers and scarfs, but don’t worry, Egypt is still a warm place as it still belongs to Africa.

What Is The Best Time To Cruise The Nile River?

    The best time to cruise the Nile River depends on your preferences and budget. Generally speaking, there are two main seasons for cruising the Nile River: winter and summer.
  • Winter (October to April): This is the peak season for cruising the Nile River, as the weather is mild and pleasant, with average temperatures ranging from 15°C to 25°C. The winter season also coincides with significant festivals and events in Egypt, such as Christmas, New Year, Coptic Easter, and Sham el-Nessim. However, winter is also the most expensive and crowded season, as many tourists flock to Egypt to escape the cold weather in their home countries. You may need to book your cruise well in advance and expect higher prices and longer queues at the attractions.
  • Summer (May to September): This is the low season for cruising the Nile River, as the weather is hot and dry, with average temperatures ranging from 25°C to 40°C. The summer season also coincides with Ramadan, the holy month of fasting for Muslims, which may affect some of the services and activities in Egypt. However, summer is also the cheapest and least crowded season, as fewer tourists visit Egypt due to the heat. You may find great deals and discounts on your cruise and enjoy more space and privacy at the attractions.

Nile Cruise Outfit Suggestions

  Many travelers wonder what to wear on a Nile cruise when they plan a trip to Egypt that includes sailing along the Nile River. Nile River cruises have no formal dress code. You can dress as you like, even on luxury Nile cruises. Your Nile cruise attire will depend mainly on the time of year you visit. You should dress casually but smartly in the evenings, especially for dinner. You can choose how to dress during the day, but the weather will also affect your decision.  

What to Wear on a Nile Cruise during Winter?

  Egypt’s winter months are December, January, and February. Egypt can get quite cold in winter, especially in the morning and at night. Average daytime temperatures in Upper Egypt are usually higher than in places like Cairo and Alexandria, while average nighttime temperatures are often lower. We recommend packing a light jacket or cardigan for winter Nile cruises in case you get cold during the day. We also strongly recommend packing a warmer and heavier jacket for the evenings if needed.  

What should you wear on a Nile Cruise during summer?

  Egypt’s summer months are June, July, and August. You can expect extreme heat in summer. You need to dress appropriately for the summer heat if you visit during this time of the year. We recommend wearing long pants that are loose-fitting and lightweight for summer Nile cruises. We also recommend wearing lightweight, long-sleeved shirts. Female Travelers can also wear long, loose-fitting dresses instead.   This will help you stay relaxed and comfortable and also protect you from the sun. You can dress however you want, but tight-fitting clothing can make you feel very uncomfortable in the summer heat.

Conclusion

Travelers who want to experience the ancient history and culture of Egypt can enjoy a Nile cruise, which offers a relaxing and scenic way to explore the river’s many attractions. From the majestic Abu Simbel temples to the mysterious Valley of the Kings, a Nile cruise can take visitors on a journey through time and space. A Nile cruise typically lasts from a few days to a week or more and includes meals, entertainment, and guided tours. The best season to book a Nile cruise is from November to February, when the weather is more relaxed and more pleasant. A Nile cruise is a must-do for anyone who loves adventure and discovery.
