Hurghada is one of the most popular and lively resort towns in Egypt, with a variety of attractions and activities to enjoy during the day and night. Whether you are looking for a relaxing or adventurous night out, Hurghada has something for everyone. Here are some tips and ideas on how to spend the night in Hurghada and answers to frequently asked questions about Hurghada nightlife.

What are the best things to do in Hurghada at night?

    Hurghada offers a wide range of things to do at night, such as:
  • Visit Hurghada Marina: Hurghada Marina is a beautiful modern marina that comes alive in the evening. Side by side are restaurants, bars, and shops. One of the best things to do in Hurghada at night is to visit Hurghada Marina at sunset. It’s such a beautiful experience to watch the sun slowly sink into the Red Sea.
 
  • Experience the nightlife: As soon as darkness descends, Hurghada transforms from a sleepy resort town into a vibrant party town. Hurghada is one of the leading nightlife cities in Egypt. There’s a large selection of discos, nightclubs, and bars serving colorful drinks and playing loud music throughout the city. Some resorts and hotels even have their very own discos and nightclubs. So why not enjoy a fun night out in Hurghada? For your safety, however, you should never go out alone at night in Hurghada. Always make sure to go out in groups.
 
  • Visit a Bedouin village: If you’re looking for an authentic thing to do in Hurghada at night, I highly recommend joining a tour of a Bedouin village. Here, you’ll be able to explore the Bedouin lifestyle in a small town in the desert. There are many different tours from Hurghada. Most major hotels and resorts offer trips to the Bedouin villages. When visiting a Bedouin village on time, you usually dress in their clothes. You’ll then be invited into a tent where you’ll be offered a tasty feast with traditional Egyptian dishes. On most tours, you can also attend an oriental show and listen to local songs.
 
  • See a show: As in most other popular resort towns worldwide, Hurghada offers many entertaining shows. You’ll be able to find everything from dance shows and concerts to magicians and more. Several of the major hotels and resorts in Hurghada offer weekly shows to their guests. It’s a good idea to investigate whether the show includes animals to avoid supporting animal cruelty.
 
  • Astronomical night trip: One of the best things to do in Hurghada at night is to go on an astronomical night trip in the desert. These tours start after dusk when you’re driven out of the city and into the lonely desert. Here, you’ll get a completely clear and undisturbed view of the starry night sky without disturbance from the city light.

What is the best time to visit Hurghada?

    Hurghada has a hot and dry climate, with mild winters and scorching summers. The best time to visit Hurghada is from October to April, when the weather is more relaxed and comfortable. Avoid the peak season of December and January, when higher prices and crowds are more significant. The summer months of May to September are scorching and dry, making sightseeing difficult and unpleasant. However, if you don’t mind the heat, you can find cheaper deals and fewer tourists during this time.

How many days do I need to explore Hurghada?

    The answer to this question depends on how much you want to see and do in Hurghada. A typical itinerary for a day tour in Hurghada would cover one or two main attractions in one city or region. For example, you can visit the beach, snorkeling, or dive in Hurghada. However, if you want to see more of Hurghada’s diversity and beauty, you may need more days to cover different destinations. For example, you can combine Hurghada with Cairo or Luxor on a day trip or overnight tour or add other places such as Alexandria, Petra (Jordan), Jerusalem (Israel), or Istanbul (Turkey) for an extended time.

How to get a visa to visit Egypt?

    Most visitors need a visa to enter Egypt, which can be obtained online or on arrival. You also need a valid passport with at least six months of validity. To apply for an online visa (e-visa), you need to fill out an application form on [the official website], pay a fee of $25 for a single-entry ticket or $60 for a multiple-entry visa, and receive your visa by email within five working days. To get access on arrival (VOA), you must pay a fee of $25 at any Egyptian airport or border crossing, fill out an application form, and receive your visa sticker on your passport. The visa is valid for 30 days from the date of entry.

What Should I Pack For My Hurghada Tour?

    Here are some tips on what to pack for your Hurghada tour:  
  • Bring comfortable shoes, hats, sunglasses, and water bottles for walking and exploring. The sun in Hurghada can be extreme and cause sunburns or heat strokes.
  • Bring sunscreen, insect repellent, and medication for common ailments. The water quality in Hurghada could be better and may cause stomach problems or infections. You should avoid raw or uncooked food, such as salads, fruits, or seafood, and only eat at reputable restaurants or hotels.
  • Bring a camera, a phone, a charger, and an adapter for your electronic devices. The electricity in Hurghada is 220 volts and 50 Hz, and the plugs are type C or F. You may need an adapter or a converter to use your devices.
  • Bring some cash in Egyptian pounds (EGP) for tipping and small purchases. Tipping is expected and appreciated in Hurghada, especially for guides, drivers, porters, waiters, and other service providers. You can tip around 10% of the bill or more, depending on the quality of service. You can also exchange your currency at banks, hotels, or exchange bureaus or withdraw money from ATMs.

As the year draws to a close, it’s a time for sharing, bonding, and spending time with those who enrich our lives. One way to embrace these sentiments is through travel. Year-end journeys have become increasingly popular, with many travelers seeking unique destinations filled with thrilling activities and itineraries. Egypt has emerged as a favored destination for December holidays, offering classic tours from Cairo and Nile River cruises (sailing between Luxor and Aswan).   December is also a time for Christmas celebrations. Recognizing that most people observe Christmas on December 25, many tourist attractions and hotels organize special events during this period. So, if you’re seeking a festive and extended Christmas holiday from mid-December to January, Egypt is the perfect destination! The pinnacle of both Christmas and New Year’s celebrations are the special dinners hosted in hotels or on River Nile Cruises. And let’s not forget the country’s iconic landmark – the Giza Pyramids, which are illuminated by the reflection of fireworks as the year turns. Additionally, on New Year’s Eve, numerous hotels host dinners featuring performances by renowned local artists.

The History Of Coptic Christmas

  Egypt is said to be the origin of the Christmas festival, including the Christmas tree. Egyptians used twelve-limbed palm trees to symbolize a completed year at the winter solstice, a tradition our Christmas tree is believed to trace back to. Interestingly, the birthdays of their sun deities were celebrated on this day. The sacred month of Kiahk is when Coptic Christmas occurs. If you find yourself in Egypt during this time, it’s recommended that you do not miss this beautiful celebration. Every Saturday, worshippers partake in a special liturgy, praying with lovely songs that enliven the mass. A unique fast is observed by the faithful for 43 days leading up to Christmas, from November 25 to January 6. This natural vegan diet called the “holy feast of the Nativity,” involves abstaining from meat and all its derivatives. However, exceptions can be made for those who are too weak or have health concerns. According to popular statistics, most foreigners celebrate Christmas and New Year in Egypt at the Red Sea in Marsa Alam and Sharm El Sheikh. They enjoy the tranquil waters of the Sea and marvel at the vibrant coral reef beneath the Sea.

Egyptian Coptic Christmas

  In the lead-up to Christmas, or Kiakh, as it’s known among Coptic Christians, the month is filled with unique customs. Predominantly, every Saturday night, hymns of praise echo through Coptic Christian churches. As dawn breaks around 5 am, Sunday Mass commences. Why not embark on a day-long adventure with our Old Cairo Tour to discover Cairo’s ancient churches? Day Tour To Coptic Cairo and Cave Church   Moreover, starting from November, 45 days before Christmas, a distinct dietary regimen commences. This diet, devoid of any animal-derived products, including butter, mirrors a vegan lifestyle. It’s a form of bodily discipline known to Christians as “the fast of the Nativity.” Themes such as discipline, sacrifice, giving, and extending kindness to others are emphasized.

Christmas Celebrating Traditions in Egypt

  Just as in the rest of the globe, Christmas in Egypt is marked by food, decorations, traditions, and celebrations! The majority of Egyptian Christians are members of the Coptic Orthodox Church, which has its own unique Christmas customs. Most Egyptian Christians are Orthodox and celebrate Christmas on January 7, following a 45-day fast from November 25 to the evening of January 6. During this period, meat, poultry, and dairy products are avoided. In the run-up to Christmas, Christian homes and churches are adorned with trees, lights, and miniature nativity scenes. On Christmas Eve, everyone dresses in new attire and heads to church, ready to partake in the festive joy. At the grand St. Mark’s Cathedral in Cairo, the Orthodox Church’s Pope commences the ceremony at 11 pm. Once the Christmas service concludes, people return home to enjoy an exceptional meal known as Fata, which includes bread, rice, garlic, and boiled meat. Visiting friends and neighbors and sharing a sweet treat called Kahk is a traditional practice. Interestingly, this confection is also enjoyed by Muslims during Eid El Fitr, which follows Ramadan.

New Year’s Eve in Egypt is All You Need To know

  Embarking on a holiday journey as the year concludes is a delightful blend of food, decorations, traditions, festivities, and a diverse array of experiences. Egypt might not be your first thought for a Christmas destination, given its Muslim-majority population. However, you’ll discover that the festive spirit is alive and well among the Egyptians. There’s a plethora of activities to enjoy during Christmas. For instance, you could embark on a serene Nile cruise, savor a delicious cup of coffee, or explore other captivating Egyptian cities such as Alexandria, Luxor, Aswan, Hurghada, Dahab, Sharm El Sheikh, and the capital, Cairo. You could indulge in retail therapy at some of Egypt’s largest and most renowned supermarkets, particularly in Sharm El Sheikh and Marsa Alam. A visit to the Egyptian Museum, the iconic Egyptian Pyramids, and the Cairo Tower is a must. Don’t miss the opportunity to capture stunning photos in front of the Sphinx or during a picturesque Nile cruise to Luxor and Aswan. Don’t let this opportunity pass you by. Book your Egyptian holiday today and send us your request for a unique and unforgettable Christmas experience with us!

How to Book And Prepare New Year’s Vacation in Egypt

   
  • Choose the best time to visit. Egypt has a hot and dry climate with mild winters, and for your information, that is what makes Christmas in Egypt a high season. You’ll find no wonder why people fall in love with the land of the pharaoh when they plan the perfect time to visit, which is from October to April when the weather is cooler and more comfortable.
 
  • Pick the right tour package. Sun Pyramids Tours, 1970, The most innovative travel agency in Egypt, is promising you an unforgettable Christmas vacation experience to live the most enjoyable and entertaining vacation on board a Nile river cruise. You can choose from the ten best family tours covering the main attractions of Cairo, Luxor, Aswan, and Hurghada, or customize your trip according to your preferences and budget. You can also combine your Egypt trip with a visit to Jordan, where you can explore the ancient city of Petra and other wonders. Check Christmas Packages
 
  • Prepare for the visa and health requirements. Most visitors need a visa to enter Egypt, which can be obtained online or on arrival. You also need a valid passport with at least six months of validity. Check the travel advice from your government for any health or safety warnings before you travel. You may need vaccinations for hepatitis A, typhoid, and yellow fever. You should also bring sunscreen, insect repellent, and medication for common ailments.
 
  • Pack smart and light. Egypt has a conservative culture, so you should dress modestly and respectfully, especially when visiting religious sites. Avoid revealing or tight clothing, and cover your shoulders and knees. However, when you are in urban and modern areas, it will look like where you live in your home country; you might notice Christmas trees everywhere, and you might meet Santa Claus as part of Egypt’s Christmas traditions. You should also bring comfortable shoes, hats, sunglasses, and water bottles for walking and exploring. Pack light and leave some space for souvenirs, such as papyrus paintings, alabaster statues, and spices.
 
  • Enjoy the diverse activities and experiences. Egypt offers a wealth of activities and experiences for Christmas and New Year holidays, such as:
    1. Marvel at the Great Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx, the most iconic symbols of ancient Egypt. You can also visit the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, where you can see the treasures of Tutankhamun and other pharaohs.
    2. Cruise the Nile on a traditional felucca or a luxury boat, and stop at various ancient sites along the way. You can visit the temples of Karnak and Luxor, the Valley of the Kings, the Temple of Hatshepsut, the Colossi of Memnon, the Temple of Kom Ombo, the Temple of Edfu, the Temple of Philae, and the Aswan High Dam.
    3. Relax on the beach or enjoy water sports in Hurghada or Sharm El Sheikh, where you can find some of the world’s best coral reefs and marine life. You can also take a day trip to the Sinai Peninsula, where you can visit Mount Sinai and St. Catherine’s Monastery.
    4. Experience the local culture and cuisine in Cairo or Alexandria, where you can find various restaurants, cafes, bars, markets, and shops. You can also watch a sound and light show at night or enjoy a [Nile dinner cruise] with live entertainment.
    5. Celebrate Coptic Christmas in January, when Egypt’s Orthodox Christians commemorate the birth of Jesus Christ. You can join them in festive prayers and rituals at their churches or homes.
    6. Ring in the New Year with fireworks and parties in Cairo or other cities, where you can find many options for entertainment and nightlife. You can also celebrate traditionally by eating grapes or lentil soup at midnight.
    7. Egypt is a magical place to visit during the Christmas and New Year holidays, as it offers a mix of adventure, culture, and relaxation. Following these tips, you can plan a memorable and enjoyable Christmas and New Year in Egypt.

post_content:
Whether it’s exploring the azure depths of the Red Sea, gazing at the stars in the expansive desert, drifting along the Nile River, or being captivated by the remnants of an ancient civilization, Egypt presents an array of travel adventures that leave holidaymakers spoilt for choice.  The dilemma for many is pinpointing the starting point of their expedition. But don’t worry. Sun Pyramids Tours is here to assist!    Sun Pyramids Tours, 1970, the most innovative travel agency in Egypt, is inviting you to embark on a remarkable journey through the Best Tourist Attractions in Egypt. And the best places to visit in Egypt.  

Cairo: A Journey Through Time - Unveiling Egypt’s Cultural and Historical Treasures

What Hidden Gems Await You in Cairo’s Cultural and Historical Landscape?

  Egypt’s vibrant capital is a treasure trove of cultural, religious, architectural, and culinary heritage. Its marvels extend beyond the confines of its renowned museums. And, of course, one of the Best Tourist Attractions in Egypt. A simple stroll down the city streets can reveal centuries of history, and a casual conversation with a local can uncover hidden gems.

  • The Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx

The last surviving wonder of the ancient world, the Pyramids of Giza are the burial monuments of the pharaohs of the 4th dynasty, who ruled Egypt more than 4,500 years ago. The Sphinx is a colossal figure of a lion with a man's head, believed to portray Pharaoh Khafre, who built the middle and the second-largest pyramid.

  • The Grand Egyptian Museum

The Grand Egyptian Museum, often referred to as the Giza Museum, is a soon-to-be-completed archaeological museum located in Giza, Egypt, approximately 2 kilometers (1.2 miles) away from the iconic Giza pyramid complex. The museum is set to house over 100,000 artifacts from the ancient Egyptian era, including the entire Tutankhamun collection, with many items being exhibited for the first time. Spanning 81,000 m2 (872,000 sq ft), it is poised to become the world’s largest museum dedicated to archaeology. The museum is a key component of the new “Giza 2030” master plan for the Giza Plateau.

  • Islamic Cairo

At the heart of the city lies Islamic Cairo, the city’s most character-filled district. Arm yourself with a camera and explore its lively lanes. Absorb the vistas from the Citadel and the ancient city gates - Bab Zuweila, Bab al-Futuh, and Bab an Nasr - and marvel at the intricate designs of the area’s magnificent mosques. The historic Mosque of Muhammad Ali, Ibn Tulun Mosque, and Al-Hakim Mosque are particularly noteworthy. Islamic Cairo also boasts the monument-rich Muizz Street and Khan El-Khalili bazaar - perfect places to pick up souvenirs (provided you’re ready to haggle).

  • Coptic Cairo

A lesser-known area is Coptic Cairo, which houses the Coptic Museum, the Hanging Church, and the towers of the long-gone Babylon fortress - a significant site for Egypt’s small Christian community since the first century CE.

  • Local tip

As night falls, Cairo comes alive with its vibrant nightlife - enjoy a drink in the historic downtown bars or catch live performances at trendy clubs and art spaces.   

Alexandria: A Blend of Ancient Grandeur and Modern Attractions

 

 What Makes Alexandria a Unique Blend of Ancient Grandeur and Modern Attractions?

  Alexandria, Egypt’s second-largest city, is a significant industrial and tourist center nestled along the Mediterranean coast. Today, Established by the legendary Alexander the Great and presided over by the iconic Queen Cleopatra, Alexandria’s origins and early years are marked by a line-up of illustrious personalities. It is undoubtedly one of the best places to visit in Egypt. Alexandria continues to charm with its blend of ancient grandeur and modern attractions, such as:

  • Bibliotheca Alexandrina

This modern library, inaugurated in 2002, is a tribute to the ancient Library of Alexandria. Its striking architecture, resembling a massive discus emerging from the sea, houses millions of books and manuscripts in various languages and disciplines. It also hosts several museums, galleries, planetariums, and cultural centers, symbolizing Alexandria’s rich artistic heritage and pursuit of knowledge.

  • Qaitbay Citadel

It may be a modest alternative for what once existed in the location of the mighty Pharos Lighthouse, which was brought down by a violent earthquake in 1303–but this compact fort has been safeguarding Alexandria since 1480. Mamluke Sultan Qaitbey constructed Fort Qaitbey in a bid to strengthen this crucial Egyptian port from assault, and debris from the fallen lighthouse was utilized in its construction. Within, you can navigate the array of stone-walled chambers and ascend to the roof to gaze out over the Mediterranean.

  • Montazah Palace

Montazah Palace is a royal palace built by Khedive Abbas II in 1892 as a summer residence for him and his family. The palace combines Turkish and Florentine styles, with elegant domes, arches, columns, and balconies. Montazah Palace is where you can enjoy some peace and tranquility away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Luxor: A Journey to the World’s Largest Open-Air Museum

 

What are the main attractions of Luxor, the ancient city of Thebes?

  Luxor, the site of the splendid ancient city of Thebes, is reputed to house a third of the world’s antiquities within the columns of its grand temples. Often referred to as the world’s largest open-air museum, and number one Egypt Tourist Attraction, this Upper Egyptian capital recently celebrated the grand reopening of the 2.7km (1.7 mile) Avenue of the Sphinxes, an age-old route linking the Karnak Temple, the abode of the renowned Temple of Amun-Ra, and the remarkably preserved Luxor Temple. A sunrise journey in a hot air balloon offers a mesmerizing aerial perspective of this city steeped in ancient marvels. Once you descend, make your way to the Hatshepsut Temple and Medinet Habu - two colossal ancient structures that frequently grace travelers’ Instagram posts. Then, cross the river to the Valley of the Kings, the royal resting place of Tutankhamun, Seti I, and Ramses II.  

  • Karnak Temple Complex

Karnak Temple Complex is a vast complex of temples, chapels, pylons, obelisks, and statues that were built over a period of 1,500 years by various pharaohs and dedicated to the god Amun and his consort Mut. Karnak Temple Complex is the largest religious complex in the world, covering an area of 200 hectares. The complex’s highlights include the Great Hypostyle Hall, which has 134 colossal columns; the Sacred Lake, used for ritual purification; and the Avenue of Sphinxes, which connects Karnak with Luxor Temple. Karnak Temple Complex is a masterpiece of ancient Egyptian architecture and art that will awe and inspire you.

  • Valley of the Kings

Valley of the Kings is a necropolis where the pharaohs and nobles of the New Kingdom were buried in rock-cut tombs that were decorated with scenes from Egyptian mythology and religion. Valley of the Kings contains more than 60 tombs, some open to the public. The most famous tomb is that of Tutankhamun, discovered in 1922 by Howard Carter, which had a wealth of treasures and artifacts. Valley of the Kings is where you can explore the secrets and mysteries of ancient Egyptian civilization and its beliefs about death and the afterlife.

  • Temple of Queen Hatshepsut

The Temple of Queen Hatshepsut is a mortuary built by Queen Hatshepsut, one of the few female pharaohs in Egyptian history who ruled from 1479 to 1458 BC. The temple is at the foot of a cliff and consists of three terraces connected by ramps and colonnades. The temple is adorned with reliefs and statues that depict various aspects of Queen Hatshepsut’s life and achievements, such as her divine birth, her expedition to Punt (a land in Africa), and her offerings to the gods. The temple is a tribute to Queen Hatshepsut’s power and glory and her contribution to Egyptian culture and art.

Aswan: A Serene Oasis in Egypt’s Nile Valley

 

What Makes Aswan a Must-Visit Destination in Egypt?

  Aswan, with its palm trees and verdant patches dotting the arid riverbanks, is one of Egypt's Tourist Attractions, renowned for the unparalleled hospitality of its Nubian inhabitants. Navigate your way to any of the 20 river islands on a felucca, the traditional wooden sailboats that traverse the Nile. To delve deeper into Nubian culture, pay a visit to Gharb Soheil Island or wander through the vibrant streets of Aswan’s Nubian Village. Savor home-cooked vegetarian or chicken tagines at local eateries, or procure fragrant spices from Aswan’s lively spice market. Aswan is celebrated for its breathtaking sunsets, which can be enjoyed from any of the islands or while cruising the Nile on a felucca. Another prime location for sunset viewing is the restaurant at the famed Sofitel Legend Old Cataract, where renowned English author Agatha Christie wrote her celebrated mystery, Death on the Nile. Local tip: If you’re up for an early start at 3 am, a day trip across the desert to Abu Simbel is a dream come true for history enthusiasts; the entire temple complex was relocated when the valley was inundated by the Aswan High Dam in the 1960s. If you prefer a later start, explore Aswan’s Temple of Isis, which was relocated from its original site on Philae Island.

Marsa Alam: Egypt’s Underwater Paradise and Beyond

 

What Makes Marsa Alam a Premier Destination for Underwater Adventures and More?

  Life certainly improves when you’re exploring vibrant coral reefs and swimming alongside dolphins, dugongs, and sea turtles in the stunning azure waters of Marsa Alam. This tranquil retreat on the western coast of the Red Sea is one of the Best Tourist Attractions for underwater adventures. Notable diving locations include the Elphinstone Reef and Abu Dabbab, renowned globally for its excellent snorkeling opportunities. For terrestrial exploits, venture to Wadi el Gemal National Park, where you can relax by the water at Hankorab Beach or embark on a safari, hike, or bike ride through the rugged mountainous landscape. Be on the lookout for camels at Sharm El Luli Beach or soak up the picturesque surroundings at the resort town of Qulaan. To gain insights into the local Bedouin community of Marsa Alam, consider a visit to the Ababda House Cultural Museum or enjoy a meal and a fragrant cup of Jebena coffee with the locals. Side trip: If you’re in search of unique mementos, make your way to Ghosoun and Hamata to meet local tribeswomen crafting distinctive hand-woven items and jewelry (each tribe boasts its own unique patterns and styles).

El Gouna: The Sunny Oasis for Digital Nomads

 

Why is El Gouna the Perfect Destination for Digital Nomads?

  It's always sunny in this fully-integrated little town along the pristine shoreline of the Red Sea, just north of Hurghada. El Gouna has become the base for a multinational community of digital nomads, young families, and expats convinced that life is better by the water. El Gouna has great aquatic activities and lots of options for hiking and safaris in the surrounding desert landscapes, which are appealing to younger travelers. It also has bougie boutiques, cultural events, and top-tier culinary experiences thanks to its many upscale restaurants, that makes it one of the Best Tourist Attractions in Egypt There are plenty of world-class services, restaurants, living spaces, coworking spaces, solid wifi connections, and lots of ways to keep busy outside of work hours – why work from home when you can work from El Gouna?

Egypt is a country that has a rich and diverse culinary heritage that dates back to ancient times. Egyptian cuisine is influenced by the geography, climate, culture, and history of the country and by the cuisines of neighboring countries and regions. Egyptian food uses fresh ingredients, aromatic spices, legumes, vegetables, and bread. In this article, we will introduce you to some of the most delicious and popular types of Egyptian food that you should try when you visit Egypt.

Bread

  Bread is a staple food in Egypt and an essential part of every meal. Egypt has different types of bread, but the most common is aish baladi, a round flatbread made from whole wheat flour baked in a clay oven. Aish Baladi is used to scoop up dips, sauces, and stews or to make sandwiches with various fillings. Other types of bread in Egypt include:

  • Aish Shamsi:

A white flatbread made from refined wheat flour that is softer and thinner than aish baladi.

  • Aish Fino:

A small bread roll similar to a French baguette but softer and lighter.

  • Aish Merahrah:

A flatbread made from millet flour that is common in rural areas.

  • Eish Saraya:

A sweet bread pudding soaked in sugar syrup and topped with nuts and cream.

  • Feteer Meshaltet:

A flaky pastry made from thin dough brushed with butter or ghee and baked in an oven. It can be eaten plain or with sweet or savory fillings.

Vegetarian

  Many types of Egyptian food are vegetarian or vegan, as meat is often expensive or reserved for special occasions. Vegetables, legumes, grains, and dairy products are widely used in Egyptian cuisine, creating nutritious, flavorful, and satisfying dishes. Some of the most popular vegetarian dishes in Egypt include:

  • Ful medames:

A paste of cooked and mashed fava beans seasoned with garlic, lemon juice, olive oil, cumin, salt, and pepper. It is served with bread, cheese, eggs, salad, or pickles for breakfast or as a snack.

  • Falafel:

Also known as Tamiya, falafel is a deep-fried patty made from ground fava beans or chickpeas mixed with parsley, onion, garlic, and spices. It is served with bread, tahini sauce, salad, or pickles as a sandwich or appetizer.

  • Koshari:

A dish of rice, brown lentils, macaroni, fried onions, and spicy tomato sauce that is considered the national dish of Egypt. It is a filling and cheap meal that can be found in street stalls and restaurants all over the country.

  • Mulukhiyah:

A soup made from chopped mallow leaves cooked with garlic, and coriander. It has a thick, slimy texture and a bitter taste balanced by lemon juice. It is served with rice, bread, and roasted chicken or rabbit as a main course.

  • Baba ganoush:

A dip made from roasted eggplant mashed with tahini, garlic, lemon juice, and olive oil. It has a smoky and creamy flavor and is served with bread, vegetables, or crackers as an appetizer or a snack.

  • Mahshi:

A dish of vegetables (such as zucchini, eggplant, cabbage, or grape leaves) stuffed with rice, herbs, and spices and cooked in tomato sauce or broth. It is a hearty and delicious meal that can be eaten with yogurt or salad.

Meat Dishes

  Although meat is not consumed as frequently as vegetables and legumes in Egypt, many Egyptian foods still feature meat as the main ingredient. Meat dishes are usually reserved for special occasions like weddings, birthdays, or religious festivals. Some of the most common meat dishes in Egypt include:

  • Kebab and kofta:

Grilled chunks of lamb (kebab) or spiced minced meat shaped into sausages (kofta) cooked on skewers over charcoal. They are served with bread, salad, and tahini sauce as a main course or appetizer.

  • Shawarma:

A thinly sliced meat (usually lamb or chicken) marinated in spices and cooked on a vertical spit. The heart is shaved off and wrapped in bread with salad, tahini sauce, and pickles as a sandwich or served on a plate with rice or fries. Shawarma is one of Egypt's most popular street foods and can be customized with different sauces and toppings.

  • Hamam:

Pigeon stuffed with rice or bulgur wheat (freek) and herbs before being roasted or grilled. It is considered a delicacy in Egypt and is often eaten at weddings or celebrations.

  • Fatta:

A dish of rice, bread, and meat (usually lamb or beef) layered on a large platter and topped with garlic vinegar sauce and fried onions. It is traditionally eaten during Eid al-Adha, the Muslim festival of sacrifice.

  • Hawawshi:

A dish of spiced minced meat stuffed into bread dough and baked in an oven. It resembles a meat pie and can be eaten as a sandwich or a main course.

  • Kebdah:

A dish of chopped liver that is cooked with garlic, chili, vinegar, and spices. It is a popular street food in Cairo and other cities and is usually eaten with bread or fries.  

Dessert

  Egyptian desserts are usually sweet, sticky, and rich in flavor. They are often made with nuts, dried fruits, honey, and pastry. They are usually served as a snack after a meal or with tea or coffee. Some of the most popular desserts in Egypt include:

  • Baklaua:

A pastry made from thin filo dough filled with chopped nuts (usually pistachios, walnuts, or almonds) and soaked in sugar syrup or honey. It is cut into small pieces and served as a bite-sized treat.

  • Basbousa:

A cake made from semolina flour soaked in sugar syrup and topped with almonds or coconut. It is moist, dense, and sweet and can be flavored with rose water or lemon juice.

  • Kunafa:

A pastry made from shredded filo dough filled with cheese or cream and soaked in sugar syrup. It is baked until golden and crispy and can be garnished with nuts or dried fruits.

  • Umm Ali:

A bread pudding made from dry bread soaked in milk and cream and baked with nuts, raisins, and coconut. It is served hot or cold and can be flavored with cinnamon or vanilla.

  • Qatayef:

A type of pancake stuffed with cheese, nuts, or cream and fried or baked. It is usually eaten during Ramadan, the Islamic fasting month, as a dessert after breaking the fast.

  • Halawa:

A sweet confection made from sesame seeds, sugar, and honey. It has a crumbly texture and can be flavored with pistachios, almonds, chocolate, or coconut.   These are some of the types of Egyptian food that you should try when you visit Egypt. They will give you a taste of the country’s culture, history, and diversity. If you want to experience these dishes and more, you can book a tour with us, and we will take you to the best places to eat in Egypt. We will also provide you with a professional guide who will explain the history and significance of each dish. Contact us today, and let us help you plan your trip to Egypt. 😊

Travel to Egypt With Children is a great destination for families who want to enjoy a mix of history, culture, and nature. If you wish to see the pyramids, cruise the Nile, or relax on the beach, Egypt has something for everyone. However, planning a family vacation in Egypt can be challenging, especially if you have different ages and interests in your group. Here are some tips and answers to frequently asked questions to help you plan a successful and memorable family vacation in Egypt.

Is Egypt A Good Destination For Families

  Yes, Egypt is a good destination for families, as it offers a variety of activities and experiences that can suit different tastes and preferences. You can learn about ancient history and civilization at the museums and archaeological sites, enjoy the scenic views and wildlife on the Nile cruise, have fun and adventure in the desert and the Red Sea, and experience the local culture and cuisine in the cities and villages. Egypt is also a relatively affordable destination, with many options for accommodation, transportation, and tours that can fit your budget.

Is Egypt Suitable For Seniors

    Yes, Egypt is suitable for seniors, as long as they are in good health and have no mobility issues. Most of the attractions in Egypt are accessible by car or bus, and some guides and assistants can help you along the way. However, some places may require walking on uneven terrain or climbing stairs, such as the pyramids, the Valley of the Kings, or the temples. You should also be aware of the weather conditions, especially the heat and the sun, and drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen. If you have any medical conditions or special needs, you should consult your doctor before traveling and bring your medication and prescriptions.

When is the best time to visit Egypt?

 
The best time to visit Egypt is from October to April when the weather is cooler and more comfortable. Avoid the peak season of December and January, when higher prices and crowds are larger. The summer months of May to September are very hot and dry, making sightseeing difficult and unpleasant. However, if you don’t mind the heat, you can find cheaper deals and fewer tourists during this time.

How Many Days Should I Stay in Egypt?

  The answer to this question depends on how much you want to see and do in Egypt. A typical itinerary for a family vacation in Egypt would cover the main attractions of Cairo, Luxor, Aswan, and Hurghada in about 10 to 14 days. However, you can extend or shorten your trip according to your interests and budget. For example, you can add more days to explore other destinations, such as Alexandria, Sharm El Sheikh, or Siwa Oasis, or skip some places if you want to focus on one or two regions.

What Can I Expect to Do on A Nile Cruise?

    A Nile Cruise is one of the best ways to experience the beauty and history of Egypt. You can sail along the longest river in the world on a traditional felucca or a luxury boat, and stop at various ancient sites. You can visit the temples of Karnak and Luxor, the Valley of the Kings, the Temple of Hatshepsut, the Colossi of Memnon, the Temple of Kom Ombo, the Temple of Edfu, the Temple of Philae, and the Aswan High Dam. You can also enjoy the scenic views of the riverbanks, watch the sunset over the water, see crocodiles and birds on the islands, and experience the local culture and cuisine on board.

Safety And Health of My Family During Trip to Egypt

 

  Egypt is generally a safe and hospitable country, but you should still take some precautions to avoid any problems or risks during your trip. Here are some tips on how to stay safe and healthy in Egypt :
  • Follow the travel advice from your government and avoid any areas affected by political unrest or violence. You can check the latest updates and warnings on their websites or apps.
  • Be aware of scams and touts that may try to overcharge you or sell you fake products or services. Do not accept any offers or invitations from strangers, and always negotiate the price before agreeing to anything. You can also ask your hotel or tour operator for recommendations or referrals.
  • Be careful of pickpockets and thieves that may target tourists in crowded or busy places. Keep your valuables and documents safely, or carry them in a hidden pouch or bag. Refrain from flaunting your money or jewelry or leaving your belongings unattended.
  • Drink only bottled water and avoid ice cubes or tap water. The water quality in Egypt could be better and may cause stomach problems or infections. You should avoid raw or uncooked food, such as salads, fruits, or seafood, and only eat at reputable restaurants or hotels.
  • Bring sunscreen, insect repellent, and medication for common ailments. The sun in Egypt can be very strong and cause sunburns or heat strokes. You should also protect yourself from mosquitoes and other insects that may carry diseases such as malaria or dengue fever. You should also bring medication for headaches, diarrhea, nausea, or allergies and any prescription drugs you need.

Souvenirs And Gifts from Egypt

    Egypt has a rich and diverse culture and produces many unique and beautiful souvenirs and gifts you can buy for your family and friends. Here are some of the most popular items that you can find in the markets and shops of Egypt:
  • Papyrus paintings: Papyrus is an ancient paper-like material used by the Egyptians to write and draw on. You can buy colorful paintings of various scenes from Egyptian mythology, history, or nature on papyrus sheets.
  • Alabaster statues: Alabaster is a soft stone carved into statues of gods, pharaohs, animals, or other figures. You can find alabaster statues of various sizes and shapes in many souvenir shops.
  • Spices: Egypt has a variety of herbs that are used in its cuisine and medicine. You can buy condiments in the spice markets or bazaars, such as cumin, coriander, cinnamon, saffron, turmeric, cardamom, cloves, nutmeg, or ginger.
  • Perfumes: Egypt is famous for its perfumes made from natural oils and essences of flowers, fruits, herbs, or wood. You can buy perfumes in bottles or vials of different shapes and colors in the perfume shops or stalls.
  • Jewelry: Egypt has a long tradition of making jewelry from gold, silver, copper, brass, or beads. You can buy jewelry such as necklaces, bracelets, earrings, rings, or pendants with various designs and motifs inspired by Egyptian culture.

How to Plan A Trip to Egypt? It might be confusing and worrying when you decide to take the adventure in a far destination like Egypt or any other far destination from your home, for it might be facing different cultures, habits, weather, and people. Here are some tips on when to go, where to go, what to know, and how to enjoy Egypt.

Why should you visit Egypt?

Egypt has the famous Pyramids of Giza and many other amazing temples and historical sites. The food is also unique and delicious. And don’t forget the Nile River, a world-renowned attraction and symbol of Egypt, and down below. You are going to know how to plan a tour to Egypt.

Facts You Should Know About Egypt

    While you Plan Tour to Egypt, You have to consider Water – Don’t drink the tap water. It has too much chlorine. Use bottled water instead. Hydration – Stay hydrated. The desert is very hot, and you can lose a lot of water. Drink plenty of water and bring electrolyte tablets for extra energy. Currency – The currency is the Egyptian pound, written £E or LE. It has smaller units called piastres. Learn the difference between the notes before you go. Expect to pay – Bring enough change with you, especially for the popular places. You can take pictures with camels or temples, but the owners will ask for money. Comfortable Clothing – Wear cotton clothes that are loose and comfortable. You are in the desert, and it’s very hot. You can get sunburned, dehydrated, or heat-exhausted. Carry water with you. Avoid the Crowds – If you don’t like crowds, go to the pyramids in the afternoon when there are fewer people. Most tourists go to the pyramids first and then to the Khan el-Khalili and Egyptian Museum. You can go to the museum after 11-12 pm when it’s less crowded. Khan el-Khalili – Don’t buy everything you see. Egypt has many beautiful things, but save your money for Khan el-Khalili. There are many items at reasonable prices. The sellers are friendly and will make your shopping fun and easy.

Best Time to Visit Egypt

    If you want to Plan A Trip to Egypt, we’ve got two main vacation times. The first one, what we call the “Christmas Season,” kicks off at the end of December. You can check out our stunning attractions during this time. But if you want to steer clear of the big crowds, consider planning your trip for mid-October through mid-November. The weather is fantastic, and prices are more budget-friendly compared to the Christmas season. The second busy season is during Easter in April, and it’s highly recommended for an amazing tour experience. You can enjoy one of our fantastic Egypt Easter tours and have the adventure you’ve been longing for. However, if scorching hot weather isn’t your thing, it’s best to steer clear of summer travel to Egypt. Summers here can get incredibly hot during the day, and it’s not advisable to go on tours, particularly in Upper Egypt, in such weather.

Best Things to Do in Egypt

   

  1. Egypt’s Historical & Cultural Tours

When it comes to Egypt, What the Best Things to Do in Egypt, the history and culture take center stage. The majority of tourists who visit Egypt come here with a specific purpose in mind – to explore the captivating historical sites found primarily in cities like Cairo, Giza, Aswan, and Alexandria. These cities are home to iconic landmarks such as the Great Pyramids, the Egyptian Museum, and the remarkable temples and tombs in Luxor and Aswan. Not to forget the Roman and Egyptian tourist attractions in Alexandria.  

  1. Egypt’s Recreational Tours

After immersing yourself in Egypt’s top attractions, it’s time to unwind and have some fun in one of the coastal cities along the Mediterranean Sea. Among the most stunning coastal destinations are Hurghada, Sharm El-Sheikh, Marsa Alam, and el-Gouna. Here, you can bask in the beauty of the sea, engage in water sports like snorkeling and scuba diving, and create unforgettable memories.  

  1. Egypt’s Adventure Tours

Egypt offers an array of experiences that guarantee an unforgettable adventure. From camping in the desert to embarking on a desert safari, exploring different islands, and partaking in a host of mesmerizing activities, you’re bound to have the time of your life.  

  1. Nile River Cruise Tours

With the longest river in the world, Egypt presents a unique opportunity to explore its treasures via a Nile River cruise. Instead of a land-based tour, consider a 4 days/3 nights Nile cruise tour from Aswan to Luxor, a 5 days/4 nights Nile cruise from Luxor to Aswan, or an 8 days/7 nights Nile cruise from Luxor to Aswan or vice versa. Our operations team will guide you through the cruise schedules and help you choose the one that best suits your itinerary for the tour of your dreams.

Best places to visit in Egypt

    Pyramids of Giza, Cairo – Of course, the pyramids are number 1 on our list of best places to visit in Egypt list. This is the last surviving of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and one of the most famous landmarks in the world. These memorials to the dead kings are still as incredible today as they were when built and should not be missed. If you’re looking for an enchanting, mystical journey to see the country as it was meant to be seen, a luxury Egypt tour will show you the whole of this great country and allow you to explore all the immortal wonders it has to offer.   Abu Simbel – Ramses II’s great temple is a special kind of temple in Egypt. At the entrance, you will see huge guards standing tall, while the inside of the pyramid has amazing wall paintings. Alexandria – This is the most European-style city in Egypt and also rich in history. The city was founded by Alexander the Great, was home to Cleopatra, and is now a seaside city from old times. Aswan – This calm town on the bends of the Nile is a beautiful place to enjoy the atmosphere and relax. Take a ferry to Elephantine Island, explore the colorful streets of Nubian Villages, or go to one of the many riverboat restaurants and cruise along the Nile. Siwa Oasis – Siwa is a peaceful oasis, a big contrast to the busy cities in Egypt. With palm plantations, water springs, and endless ancient mud-brick buildings, there are many scenic spots around the city to explore. Islamic Cairo – Also known as historic Cairo or medieval Cairo, this area of the city has many ancient buildings around the walled city. Go to one of the many mosques, shrines, mausoleums, walls, gates, and markets in the area to get a glimpse of ancient Egypt. White Desert – This natural wonder is a quirky, unique site in Egypt. Small chalk mountains are coming out of the white desert, creating a landscape that looks like a sci-fi movie.

Accommodation in Egypt

 
Selecting the right place to stay plays a vital role in enhancing your overall travel experience in Egypt. The country provides a diverse range of accommodation options, catering to various budgets and preferences, ensuring your stay is both comfortable and memorable.
Hotels are the most common lodging choice in Egypt, offering options from budget to luxury. Major cities like Cairo, Luxor, and Aswan boast a variety of hotels to cater to different traveler needs. These establishments provide amenities such as cozy rooms, on-site restaurants, and additional facilities like swimming pools and fitness centers. They’re a convenient option for those seeking easy access to city attractions and a range of services. Resorts are another favored choice, especially in coastal destinations like Sharm El Sheikh and Hurghada along the Red Sea. Resorts promise comfort, relaxation, and entertainment, with features like private beaches, swimming pools, and various activities. They’re perfect for travelers looking to unwind, enjoy water sports, and partake in all-inclusive packages. For a distinctive experience, consider a Nile cruise, particularly if your itinerary involves Luxor and Aswan. Nile cruises offer a unique perspective of Egypt, blending comfortable accommodation with a floating journey along the iconic Nile River. These cruises often include guided tours to significant historical sites, allowing you to explore ancient temples and tombs while enjoying onboard amenities and scenic views. When picking accommodation, it’s crucial to consider popular areas within major cities and tourist destinations. In Cairo, areas like Downtown and Zamalek provide convenient access to historical sites, museums, and vibrant markets. Luxor’s East Bank and Aswan’s Corniche are popular areas featuring a variety of hotels and beautiful Nile views. Factor in your budget, desired location, and personal preferences to ensure you choose suitable accommodation. If you’re on a budget, look for wallet-friendly hotels or consider guesthouses and hostels. If proximity to attractions matters, opt for centrally located accommodations. Research traveler reviews and ratings to gauge the quality and service of the lodging. Additionally, consider amenities and facilities that matter to you, be it a swimming pool, Wi-Fi access, or an in-house restaurant. By exploring diverse accommodation options, understanding popular areas, and aligning choices with your budget and preferences, you can make an informed decision. Booking accommodation in advance, especially during peak travel seasons, ensures you secure the best options. Rest assured that Egypt offers a broad spectrum of accommodations to suit every traveler, promising a comfortable and enjoyable stay in this captivating country.

Transportation Options in Egypt

 

  When it comes to getting around Egypt, you’ve got a bunch of ways to roll, each with its own perks and things to think about. Knowing what’s out there and what works best for different types of travelers is key to having a hassle-free trip. So, first up, flights. They’re your go-to for covering long distances in Egypt in a flash. The country’s airports are all connected, making it a breeze to hit up the hotspots. If you’re short on time or just want a quick and comfy ride, domestic flights are the ticket. But keep in mind, they might dent your wallet a bit more than other choices. Then there are trains, a solid pick for cruising between the big cities. They’re comfy, won’t break the bank, and let you soak in some awesome views of the Egyptian countryside. Trains are for those who want a bit of both – a decent ride without burning a hole in their pocket. Tip: snag your train tickets early, especially when everyone’s on the move. If you’re on a budget and looking for an authentic local vibe, buses are the way to go. Egypt’s got a network covering cities and towns, offering a wallet-friendly option. Buses take a bit longer, but they’re perfect for the penny-pinchers or those who love to dive deep into the travel scene. Just know, not all buses are created equal, so do some homework on the reliable ones and grab your tickets ahead of time. To ace the transportation game in Egypt, think about your travel needs, what you dig, and your budget. Need speed? Fly domestic. Want a mix of comfort and cash saved? Hop on a train. Craving local vibes and got time to spare? Bus it up. And don’t forget, hit up the trusted providers or local travel wizards when sorting your tickets. Watch out for the peak times and holidays – everyone’s on the move. Also, give yourself some wiggle room for transfers and connections, especially if you’re blending different ways of getting around. Knowing your options, weighing the pros and cons, and planning ahead – that’s the ticket to smoothly cruising through Egypt. Enjoy the ride in this fascinating country! Just remember that Sun Pyramids Agency is offering private transportation with modern air-conditioned vehicles at competitive prices.

Getting a Visa in Egypt

    The first thing when you plan Tour to Egypt is getting An Egypt e-Visa, which is an online entry permit that you can apply for seven days before travel. The Egyptian government issues it to eligible countries. The e-Visa is fast and cheap, unlike the traditional Embassy visas that take a lot of time and money. You can choose between a single-entry or a multiple-entry E-Visa. You can use both for tourism or business.

Types of Egypt E-Visa

There are two types of e-Visa; pick the one that suits your travel needs.

Single Entry E-Visa

The single e-visa for 30 days is valid for 90 days from the date of issue. You can visit Egypt once during your validity period for work or tourism.

Multiple Entry E-Visa

The multiple e-Visa for 30 days lets you stay 30 days. Multiple Egypt e-Visa allows you to stay in Egypt for six months from the date of issuing. The multiple e-visa expires after six months. During your validity period, you are allowed to visit Egypt at any time and stay for 30 days.   Additionally, you can enter and exit the country multiple times within a six-month validity period.

Customize Your Egypt Tour with a Reliable Tour Operator

Experienced Guides: Knowledgeable tour guides and drivers to enhance your experience. Customization: Clear communication with your tour operator to create a personalized itinerary.
